questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents to you with intellectual disability and hearing loss and you notice the following external ear anomaly. What could be the anomaly in this case be?

options.label: A
options.text: Ganglion

options.label: B
options.text: Preauricular sinus

options.label: C
options.text: Preauricular tag

options.label: D
options.text: Neurodermatitis

questions.correct_answer: C. Preauricular tag
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Preauricular Tag

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preauricular tags are congenital external ear anomalies that may be isolated or syndromic (e.g., Goldenhar syndrome). Any newborn with external ear anomalies should undergo hearing screening and evaluation for associated syndromes, as these anomalies may indicate underlying structural or genetic conditions affecting craniofacial development.
  • ➤ Preauricular tags are congenital external ear anomalies that may be isolated or syndromic (e.g., Goldenhar syndrome). Any newborn with external ear anomalies should undergo hearing screening and evaluation for associated syndromes, as these anomalies may indicate underlying structural or genetic conditions affecting craniofacial development.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 51
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 51

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen left ear following a physical altercation. On examination, the left auricle is markedly swollen and deformed with a fluctuant, non-erythematous area occupying most of the antihelical fold. There is no laceration or discharge, and the patient denies any hearing loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Cold compress and analgesics

options.label: B
options.text: Incision and drainage followed by pressure dressing

options.label: C
options.text: Oral antibiotics and outpatient follow-up

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate referral for plastic surgery consultation

questions.correct_answer: B. Incision and drainage followed by pressure dressing
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Incision and Drainage Followed by Pressure Dressing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auricular hematomas should be managed promptly with incision and drainage followed by a pressure dressing to prevent cartilage necrosis and permanent deformity (cauliflower ear). Cold compresses, antibiotics, or plastic surgery consultation alone are not sufficient initial treatments.
  • ➤ Auricular hematomas should be managed promptly with incision and drainage followed by a pressure dressing to prevent cartilage necrosis and permanent deformity (cauliflower ear).
  • ➤ Auricular hematomas should be managed promptly with incision and drainage followed by a pressure dressing
  • ➤ cartilage necrosis and permanent deformity (cauliflower ear).
  • ➤ Cold compresses, antibiotics, or plastic surgery consultation alone are not sufficient initial treatments.
  • ➤ Cold compresses, antibiotics, or plastic surgery consultation alone are not sufficient initial treatments.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for a pinnaplasty due to prominent ears. The parents inquire about the rationale for choosing this age for the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate reason for performing pinnaplasty at this age?

options.label: A
options.text: Ear cartilage has reached full adult size.

options.label: B
options.text: Chondral cartilage (graft) matures adequately

options.label: C
options.text: Prevention of psychological distress from peer teasing.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.correct_answer: D. All of the above
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the Above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pinnaplasty (Otoplasty) is ideally performed at around 6 years of age because: The external ear has reached near-adult size (~85–90%) . The cartilage is mature yet flexible enough for reshaping . Psychological distress from peer teasing can be prevented . A combination of these factors makes 6 years the optimal time for the procedure.
  • ➤ Pinnaplasty (Otoplasty) is ideally performed at around 6 years of age because: The external ear has reached near-adult size (~85–90%) . The cartilage is mature yet flexible enough for reshaping . Psychological distress from peer teasing can be prevented . A combination of these factors makes 6 years the optimal time for the procedure.
  • ➤ Pinnaplasty (Otoplasty) is ideally performed at around 6 years of age
  • ➤ The external ear has reached near-adult size (~85–90%) . The cartilage is mature yet flexible enough for reshaping . Psychological distress from peer teasing can be prevented . A combination of these factors makes 6 years the optimal time for the procedure.
  • ➤ The external ear has reached near-adult size (~85–90%) .
  • ➤ The external ear has reached near-adult size (~85–90%)
  • ➤ The cartilage is mature yet flexible enough for reshaping .
  • ➤ The cartilage is mature yet flexible enough for reshaping
  • ➤ Psychological distress from peer teasing can be prevented . A combination of these factors makes 6 years the optimal time for the procedure.
  • ➤ Psychological distress from peer teasing can be prevented

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a three-day history of pain and swelling in his right ear. He has no significant past medical history but recalls scratching his ear with a toothpick a few days ago. On examination, the right pinna is erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch, especially around the cartilage. There is no discharge or fluctuance, and the auditory canal appears normal. The tympanic membrane is intact and mobile. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral Antivirals and Analgesics

options.label: B
options.text: Oral Antibiotics and Analgesics

options.label: C
options.text: Incision and Drainage

options.label: D
options.text: Topical Antibiotic Ear Drops

questions.correct_answer: B. Oral Antibiotics and Analgesics
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oral Antibiotics and Analgesics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular cartilage , commonly occurring after trauma and often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa . Early recognition and treatment with systemic antibiotics (fluoroquinolones) are crucial to prevent cartilage necrosis and auricular deformity . Incision and drainage are reserved for abscess formation , and topical antibiotics are ineffective for deep cartilage infections .
  • ➤ Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular cartilage , commonly occurring after trauma and often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa . Early recognition and treatment with systemic antibiotics (fluoroquinolones) are crucial to prevent cartilage necrosis and auricular deformity . Incision and drainage are reserved for abscess formation , and topical antibiotics are ineffective for deep cartilage infections .
  • ➤ Perichondritis
  • ➤ infection of the auricular cartilage
  • ➤ after trauma
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • ➤ Early recognition and treatment with systemic antibiotics (fluoroquinolones) are crucial
  • ➤ cartilage necrosis and auricular deformity
  • ➤ Incision and drainage are reserved for abscess formation
  • ➤ topical antibiotics are ineffective for deep cartilage infections
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a small pit near her right ear, which has been present since birth. On examination, a small opening is noted anterior to the ascending limb of the helix of the right ear. There is no redness, swelling, or drainage at the time of the visit. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical Excision of the Sinus Tract

options.label: B
options.text: Topical Antibiotic Ointment Application

options.label: C
options.text: Systemic Antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Observation and Hygiene Education

questions.correct_answer: D. Observation and Hygiene Education
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Observation and Hygiene Education

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A preauricular sinus is a congenital defect resulting from incomplete fusion of the first and second pharyngeal arches . Asymptomatic cases require only observation and hygiene education . Surgical excision and antibiotics are reserved for infected or recurrently symptomatic cases.
  • ➤ A preauricular sinus is a congenital defect resulting from incomplete fusion of the first and second pharyngeal arches .
  • ➤ preauricular sinus
  • ➤ congenital defect resulting from incomplete fusion of the first and second pharyngeal arches
  • ➤ Asymptomatic cases require only observation and hygiene education . Surgical excision and antibiotics are reserved for infected or recurrently symptomatic cases.
  • ➤ Asymptomatic cases require only observation and hygiene education
  • ➤ Surgical excision and antibiotics are reserved for infected or recurrently symptomatic cases.
  • ➤ Ref. P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.
  • ➤ Ref. P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of temporomandibular joint (TMJ) pain and occasional otorrhea, especially after chewing. Examination reveals a small opening in the antero-inferior part of the bony ear canal. This anatomical variation is known as the foramen of Huschke. What is the most likely clinical significance of this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased risk of Cholesteatoma formation

options.label: B
options.text: Potential for spread of infection from the TMJ to the ear

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormality leading to conductive hearing loss

options.label: D
options.text: Increased risk of otosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Potential for spread of infection from the TMJ to the ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Potential for spread of infection from the TMJ to the Ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The foramen of Huschke is a congenital defect in the antero-inferior bony external auditory canal that creates a communication between the TMJ and the ear . This can lead to the spread of TMJ infections to the ear , causing otorrhea, ear pain, and symptoms that worsen with chewing .
  • ➤ The foramen of Huschke is a congenital defect in the antero-inferior bony external auditory canal that creates a communication between the TMJ and the ear .
  • ➤ foramen of Huschke
  • ➤ congenital defect in the antero-inferior bony external auditory canal
  • ➤ communication between the TMJ and the ear
  • ➤ This can lead to the spread of TMJ infections to the ear , causing otorrhea, ear pain, and symptoms that worsen with chewing .
  • ➤ can lead to the spread of TMJ infections to the ear
  • ➤ otorrhea, ear pain, and symptoms that worsen with chewing
  • ➤ Ref. P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.
  • ➤ Ref. P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a laceration on the upper part of his left ear following a minor car accident. He reports numbness in the area surrounding the laceration. On examination, the laceration involves the helix but does not extend to the external auditory canal. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient's injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Greater Auricular Nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Lesser Occipital Nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Auriculotemporal Nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Arnold's Nerve (a branch of the Vagus Nerve)

questions.correct_answer: A. Greater Auricular Nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Greater Auricular Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Greater Auricular Nerve (C2, C3) is the primary sensory nerve for most of the external ear, including the helix and lobule . Injury to this nerve during trauma can cause numbness in these regions . The auriculotemporal nerve, lesser occipital nerve, and Arnold’s nerve provide sensation to other parts of the ear but do not primarily supply the helix.
  • ➤ The Greater Auricular Nerve (C2, C3) is the primary sensory nerve for most of the external ear, including the helix and lobule .
  • ➤ Greater Auricular Nerve (C2, C3) is the primary sensory nerve for most of the external ear, including the helix and lobule
  • ➤ Injury to this nerve during trauma can cause numbness in these regions .
  • ➤ Injury to this nerve during trauma can cause numbness in these regions
  • ➤ The auriculotemporal nerve, lesser occipital nerve, and Arnold’s nerve provide sensation to other parts of the ear but do not primarily supply the helix.
  • ➤ The auriculotemporal nerve, lesser occipital nerve, and Arnold’s nerve provide sensation to other parts of the ear but do not primarily supply the helix.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 4.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 4.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for a routine check-up. The parents express concern about the shape of the child's ears, which they describe as small and underdeveloped. On examination, the child's ears are noted to be smaller than normal with poorly formed helices and lobules, resembling a peanut shape. The child has normal hearing. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with this ear deformity?

options.label: A
options.text: Turner Syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Treacher Collins Syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Down Syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Microtia

questions.correct_answer: D. Microtia
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Microtia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "peanut ear" deformity, characterized by small, underdeveloped ears with poorly formed helices and lobules, is most commonly associated with microtia. Microtia is a congenital external ear malformation that can range in severity and may be associated with other craniofacial anomalies or occur in isolation.
  • ➤ The "peanut ear" deformity, characterized by small, underdeveloped ears with poorly formed helices and lobules, is most commonly associated with microtia.
  • ➤ Microtia is a congenital external ear malformation that can range in severity and may be associated with other craniofacial anomalies or occur in isolation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 48.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 48.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the clinic with pain and swelling in front of her left ear. She has a history of a small pit in that area since birth but has never had any problems until now. On examination, there is erythema, tenderness, and swelling anterior to the tragus of the left ear, and a small amount of purulent discharge is noted from a pit in the same region. There is no fever or hearing loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Incision and drainage of the sinus

options.label: B
options.text: Systemic antibiotics targeting skin flora

options.label: C
options.text: Topical antibiotic ointment application

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical excision of the sinus tract

questions.correct_answer: B. Systemic antibiotics targeting skin flora
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Systemic Antibiotics Targeting Skin Flora

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate initial management for an infected preauricular sinus is systemic antibiotics targeting common skin flora (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp.) . Surgical excision is reserved for recurrent or complicated cases . Incision and drainage are needed only in cases of abscess formation .
  • ➤ The appropriate initial management for an infected preauricular sinus is systemic antibiotics targeting common skin flora (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp.) . Surgical excision is reserved for recurrent or complicated cases . Incision and drainage are needed only in cases of abscess formation .
  • ➤ appropriate initial management for an infected preauricular sinus is systemic antibiotics targeting common skin flora (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp.)
  • ➤ Surgical excision is reserved for recurrent or complicated cases
  • ➤ Incision and drainage are needed only in cases of abscess formation
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of a progressively enlarging, raised scar on her left earlobe following a piercing six months ago. On examination, the lesion is firm, rubbery, and larger than the original wound, extending beyond the borders of the initial piercing site. The patient reports that the lesion is occasionally itchy and painful. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Topical Antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Intralesional Corticosteroid Injections

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical Excision

options.label: D
options.text: Application of Silicone Gel Sheets

questions.correct_answer: B. Intralesional Corticosteroid Injections
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intralesional Corticosteroid Injections

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keloids are hypertrophic scars that extend beyond the original wound margins due to excessive collagen deposition. First-line treatment includes intralesional corticosteroid injections, which help reduce size, inflammation, and pruritus. Surgical excision has a high recurrence rate unless combined with adjunctive therapy.
  • ➤ Keloids are hypertrophic scars that extend beyond the original wound margins due to excessive collagen deposition.
  • ➤ Keloids are hypertrophic scars that extend beyond the original wound margins due to excessive collagen deposition.
  • ➤ First-line treatment includes intralesional corticosteroid injections, which help reduce size, inflammation, and pruritus.
  • ➤ First-line treatment includes intralesional corticosteroid injections, which help reduce size, inflammation, and pruritus.
  • ➤ Surgical excision has a high recurrence rate unless combined with adjunctive therapy.
  • ➤ Surgical excision has a high recurrence rate unless combined with adjunctive therapy.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 50.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 50.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen left ear. He has a history of ear piercing two weeks ago. On examination, the upper part of the ear is erythematous, tender, and edematous, with sparing of the earlobe. The external auditory canal and tympanic membrane are normal. Which microorganism is most commonly responsible for this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Staphylococcus Aureus

options.label: B
options.text: Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

options.label: C
options.text: Aspergillus Niger

options.label: D
options.text: Streptococcus Pyogenes

questions.correct_answer: B. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular cartilage, most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, particularly following ear piercing or trauma. The earlobe is typically spared, distinguishing it from cellulitis. Prompt antibiotic treatment with fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) is essential to prevent cartilage necrosis and ear deformity.
  • ➤ Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular cartilage, most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, particularly following ear piercing or trauma.
  • ➤ The earlobe is typically spared, distinguishing it from cellulitis. Prompt antibiotic treatment with fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) is essential to prevent cartilage necrosis and ear deformity.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 50.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 50.

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections characterized by drainage from an opening in the neck just below and behind the angle of the mandible and another opening in the external auditory canal. These findings are consistent with a collaural fistula, an abnormality of the first branchial cleft. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibiotic therapy and observation

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical excision of the fistula

options.label: C
options.text: Corticosteroid therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Hearing assessment and rehabilitation

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgical excision of the fistula
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Surgical Excision of the Fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A collaural fistula , a first branchial cleft anomaly , requires surgical excision to prevent recurrent infections and complications . Antibiotics may be used to treat acute infections , but they do not provide a definitive cure. The fistula runs near the facial nerve, requiring careful surgical dissection to avoid nerve damage .
  • ➤ A collaural fistula , a first branchial cleft anomaly , requires surgical excision to prevent recurrent infections and complications .
  • ➤ collaural fistula
  • ➤ first branchial cleft anomaly
  • ➤ surgical excision to prevent recurrent infections and complications
  • ➤ Antibiotics may be used to treat acute infections , but they do not provide a definitive cure.
  • ➤ Antibiotics may be used to treat acute infections
  • ➤ The fistula runs near the facial nerve, requiring careful surgical dissection to avoid nerve damage .
  • ➤ The fistula runs near the facial nerve, requiring careful surgical dissection to avoid nerve damage
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 50-51.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 50-51.

questions.text: During embryonic development, the pinna (auricle) forms from contributions of specific embryonic structures. Which of the following correctly identifies the embryonic origin of the pinna?

options.label: A
options.text: Neural crest cells from the first pharyngeal arch

options.label: B
options.text: Mesoderm of the second pharyngeal arch

options.label: C
options.text: Ectodermal hillocks of the first and second pharyngeal arches

options.label: D
options.text: Endodermal contributions from the first pharyngeal pouch

questions.correct_answer: C. Ectodermal hillocks of the first and second pharyngeal arches
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ectodermal Hillocks of the First and Second Pharyngeal Arches

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pinna (auricle) develops from six ectodermal hillocks located around the first and second pharyngeal arches , which fuse and remodel to form the external ear . The first pharyngeal arch contributes to the tragus and upper helix, while the second pharyngeal arch forms the remaining auricular structures .
  • ➤ The pinna (auricle) develops from six ectodermal hillocks located around the first and second pharyngeal arches , which fuse and remodel to form the external ear .
  • ➤ pinna (auricle) develops from six ectodermal hillocks
  • ➤ first and second pharyngeal arches
  • ➤ fuse and remodel
  • ➤ external ear
  • ➤ The first pharyngeal arch contributes to the tragus and upper helix, while the second pharyngeal arch forms the remaining auricular structures .
  • ➤ The first pharyngeal arch contributes to the tragus and upper helix, while the second pharyngeal arch forms the remaining auricular structures
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 48.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 48.

questions.text: A wrestler presents to your OPD with the following ear deformity. What is the most likely cause for this?

options.label: A
options.text: Auricular cyst

options.label: B
options.text: Avulsion of pinna

options.label: C
options.text: External ear exostosis

options.label: D
options.text: Auricular hematoma

questions.correct_answer: D. Auricular hematoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Auricular Hematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auricular hematoma occurs due to blunt trauma, leading to blood accumulation between cartilage and perichondrium. If untreated, it progresses to cauliflower ear, a permanent deformity. Immediate aspiration, pressure dressing, and prophylactic antibiotics are key to preventing complications.
  • ➤ Auricular hematoma occurs due to blunt trauma, leading to blood accumulation between cartilage and perichondrium.
  • ➤ If untreated, it progresses to cauliflower ear, a permanent deformity. Immediate aspiration, pressure dressing, and prophylactic antibiotics are key to preventing complications.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A newborn present with the following condition bilaterally and with external auditory canal atresia. Corrective surgery is usually performed at

options.label: A
options.text: < 1 year of age

options.label: B
options.text: 6 years of age

options.label: C
options.text: Puberty

options.label: D
options.text: Adulthood

questions.correct_answer: B. 6 years of age
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6 years of age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microtia is a congenital ear anomaly that requires auricular reconstruction, optimally performed between 6 years of age when the ear has grown sufficiently, and rib cartilage is available. External auditory canal atresia often coexists, requiring bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA) or canaloplasty for hearing rehabilitation.
  • ➤ Microtia is a congenital ear anomaly that requires auricular reconstruction, optimally performed between 6 years of age when the ear has grown sufficiently, and rib cartilage is available.
  • ➤ External auditory canal atresia often coexists, requiring bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA) or canaloplasty for hearing rehabilitation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: Patient presents to you with a painful ear swelling, what is the likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Otitis externa

options.label: B
options.text: Cauliflower ear

options.label: C
options.text: Perichondritis

options.label: D
options.text: Chondrodermatitis helicis

questions.correct_answer: C. Perichondritis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perichondritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perichondritis is a painful infection of the auricular cartilage, commonly due to trauma or extension of infection from otitis externa. It is most often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and requires prompt antibiotic therapy to prevent cartilage destruction and deformity.
  • ➤ Perichondritis is a painful infection of the auricular cartilage, commonly due to trauma or extension of infection from otitis externa.
  • ➤ It is most often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and requires prompt antibiotic therapy to prevent cartilage destruction and deformity.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: Which nerve DOES NOT supply the pinna?

options.label: A
options.text: Greater Auricular Nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Arnolds Nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Facial Nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Jacobson’s Nerve

questions.correct_answer: D. Jacobson’s Nerve
questions.explanation:

questions.text: IDENTIFY?

options.label: A
options.text: Pre-auricular appendages

options.label: B
options.text: Peanut ear

options.label: C
options.text: Lop ear

options.label: D
options.text: Anotia

questions.correct_answer: B. Peanut ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Peanut Ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peanut ear is a severe form of microtia, characterized by a small, malformed, folded auricle, often associated with external auditory canal, middle ear, and inner ear anomalies leading to hearing loss. Early evaluation and auricular reconstruction (typically at 6 years of age) are important for functional and cosmetic correction.
  • ➤ Peanut ear is a severe form of microtia, characterized by a small, malformed, folded auricle, often associated with external auditory canal, middle ear, and inner ear anomalies leading to hearing loss.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presented with pain and swelling in front of the left ear for 2 days. She had a similar episode in the past 3 yrs. The examination finding is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Preauricular lymphadenitis

options.label: B
options.text: Infected Parotid cyst

options.label: C
options.text: Infected preauricular sinus

options.label: D
options.text: Epidermal inclusion cyst

questions.correct_answer: C. Infected preauricular sinus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Infected Preauricular Sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A preauricular sinus is a congenital pit-like anomaly caused by defective fusion of the hillocks of His from the 1 st and 2 nd branchial arches. It can become infected, leading to pain and pus discharge, requiring antibiotics and eventual surgical excision to prevent recurrence.
  • ➤ A preauricular sinus is a congenital pit-like anomaly caused by defective fusion of the hillocks of His from the 1 st and 2 nd branchial arches.
  • ➤ It can become infected, leading to pain and pus discharge, requiring antibiotics and eventual surgical excision to prevent recurrence.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about treatment of frostbite?

options.label: A
options.text: Rewarming with moist cotton pledgets at a temperature of 38–42°C,

options.label: B
options.text: Application of 0.5% silver nitrate soaks for superficial infection,

options.label: C
options.text: Protection of bullae from rupture

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate surgical debridement of dead tissues

questions.correct_answer: D. Immediate surgical debridement of dead tissues
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Immediate surgical debridement of dead tissues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frostbite management involves rapid rewarming, infection prevention, and tissue preservation. Early surgical debridement is avoided to allow for natural tissue demarcation, ensuring only non-viable tissue is removed at a later stage.
  • ➤ Frostbite management involves rapid rewarming, infection prevention, and tissue preservation.
  • ➤ Early surgical debridement is avoided to allow for natural tissue demarcation, ensuring only non-viable tissue is removed at a later stage.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49-50
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49-50

questions.text: A 26yr old female presented with firm, non-tender swelling over the ear since 3yrs which she developed following a second ear piercing.

options.label: A
options.text: Keloid

options.label: B
options.text: Hypertrophied scar

options.label: C
options.text: Epidermoid cyst

options.label: D
options.text: Sebaceous cyst

questions.correct_answer: A. Keloid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Keloid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keloids are excessive fibrous tissue overgrowths that develop after trauma, burns, or surgery, extending beyond the wound margins. They are common after ear piercings , particularly in individuals with genetic predisposition. Management includes surgical excision combined with steroid injections to prevent recurrence .
  • ➤ Keloids are excessive fibrous tissue overgrowths that develop after trauma, burns, or surgery, extending beyond the wound margins.
  • ➤ They are common after ear piercings , particularly in individuals with genetic predisposition.
  • ➤ ear piercings
  • ➤ genetic
  • ➤ Management includes surgical excision combined with steroid injections to prevent recurrence .
  • ➤ surgical excision
  • ➤ steroid
  • ➤ recurrence
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 50
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 50

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented with complaints of right swollen pinna as shown in the picture since 1 week, that was progressively worsening. Patient had ear piercing 2 weeks ago. Patient was a non-diabetic and in good health, with no other significant past medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Contact dermatitis

options.label: B
options.text: Perichondritis

options.label: C
options.text: Cellulitis

options.label: D
options.text: Otitis externa

questions.correct_answer: B. Perichondritis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perichondritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular perichondrium, often triggered by trauma, ear piercing, or surgery. It presents with red, swollen, painful, and stiff pinna and is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Prompt antibiotic therapy and abscess drainage (if needed) are essential to prevent cartilage necrosis and ear deformity.
  • ➤ Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular perichondrium, often triggered by trauma, ear piercing, or surgery.
  • ➤ It presents with red, swollen, painful, and stiff pinna and is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • ➤ Prompt antibiotic therapy and abscess drainage (if needed) are essential to prevent cartilage necrosis and ear deformity.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 50
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 50

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the ENT clinic by his parents due to concerns about his ears appearing prominently protruded since birth. Examination reveals a large concha with underdeveloped antihelix and scapha. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bat ear (Prominent ear)

options.label: B
options.text: Microtia

options.label: C
options.text: Cauliflower ear

options.label: D
options.text: Preauricular tag

questions.correct_answer: A. Bat ear (Prominent ear)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bat Ear (Prominent Ear)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bat ear (Prominent ear) is a congenital condition caused by underdeveloped antihelix and scapha with a large concha , leading to an ear that sticks out excessively. It is purely cosmetic and can be corrected via otoplasty after 6 years of age for psychological and aesthetic concerns.
  • ➤ Bat ear (Prominent ear) is a congenital condition caused by underdeveloped antihelix and scapha with a large concha , leading to an ear that sticks out excessively.
  • ➤ underdeveloped antihelix and scapha with a large concha
  • ➤ It is purely cosmetic and can be corrected via otoplasty after 6 years of age for psychological and aesthetic concerns.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48
