questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a deep laceration of the left pinna, sustained in a road traffic accident. Examination reveals a complex laceration involving the skin, perichondrium, and cartilage, as seen in the image. What is the best immediate management approach?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary closure with absorbable sutures for perichondrium and nonabsorbable sutures for skin

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate debridement with cartilage excision and skin grafting

options.label: C
options.text: Leave the wound open to heal by secondary intention

options.label: D
options.text: Apply a simple pressure dressing and follow up in one week

questions.correct_answer: A. Primary closure with absorbable sutures for perichondrium and nonabsorbable sutures for skin
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Primary closure with absorbable sutures for perichondrium and nonabsorbable sutures for skin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ear pinna lacerations require early surgical repair to preserve cartilage viability and prevent deformities. The perichondrium must be sutured with absorbable sutures, and the skin should be closed with nonabsorbable sutures. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are recommended to prevent infection.
  • ➤ Ear pinna lacerations require early surgical repair to preserve cartilage viability and prevent deformities.
  • ➤ The perichondrium must be sutured with absorbable sutures, and the skin should be closed with nonabsorbable sutures. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are recommended to prevent infection.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with anomalous ear positioning, noticed since birth. Examination reveals that the upper third of the auricle is embedded under the scalp skin, making it difficult for the ear to protrude normally. Based on the clinical image, what is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Cryptotia (Pocket Ear)

options.label: B
options.text: Microtia

options.label: C
options.text: Bat Ear (Prominent Ear)

options.label: D
options.text: Lop Ear

questions.correct_answer: A. Cryptotia (Pocket Ear)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cryptotia (Pocket Ear)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptotia (Pocket Ear) is a congenital ear deformity where the upper third of the ear is embedded under the scalp, preventing normal protrusion. Surgical correction involves mobilizing the ear and performing a skin graft to restore the natural contour.
  • ➤ Cryptotia (Pocket Ear) is a congenital ear deformity where the upper third of the ear is embedded under the scalp, preventing normal protrusion.
  • ➤ Surgical correction involves mobilizing the ear and performing a skin graft to restore the natural contour.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the ENT clinic for evaluation of an ear deformity noticed at birth. Examination reveals a transverse cleft in the middle of the auricle, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Coloboma of the Pinna

options.label: B
options.text: Microtia

options.label: C
options.text: Cryptotia

options.label: D
options.text: Preauricular Sinus

questions.correct_answer: A. Coloboma of the Pinna
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coloboma of the Pinna

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coloboma of the pinna is a congenital auricular anomaly presenting as a transverse cleft in the middle of the auricle, due to improper fusion of auricular hillocks. It may be isolated or part of syndromic conditions (e.g., Treacher Collins syndrome). Surgical reconstruction is the treatment of choice for severe cases.
  • ➤ Coloboma of the pinna is a congenital auricular anomaly presenting as a transverse cleft in the middle of the auricle, due to improper fusion of auricular hillocks.
  • ➤ It may be isolated or part of syndromic conditions (e.g., Treacher Collins syndrome).
  • ➤ Surgical reconstruction is the treatment of choice for severe cases.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, where his external ear was partially torn but still attached by a small pedicle of skin. What is the best management approach?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary reattachment of the pinna

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate removal of the avulsed segment and skin grafting

options.label: C
options.text: Leaving the wound open to heal by secondary intention

options.label: D
options.text: Suturing the skin without addressing the cartilage

questions.correct_answer: A. Primary reattachment of the pinna
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Primary reattachment of the pinna

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pinna avulsion injuries require immediate surgical attention. Primary reattachment should always be attempted if the pinna is partially attached, while microvascular reimplantation may be attempted for complete avulsions. In cases where reimplantation is not possible, cartilage can be implanted under postauricular skin for later reconstruction.
  • ➤ Pinna avulsion injuries require immediate surgical attention. Primary reattachment should always be attempted if the pinna is partially attached, while microvascular reimplantation may be attempted for complete avulsions. In cases where reimplantation is not possible, cartilage can be implanted under postauricular skin for later reconstruction.
  • ➤ immediate surgical
  • ➤ Primary reattachment

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the ENT clinic for a routine checkup. On examination, a small, pointed tubercle is seen on the upper part of the helix of his external ear, as indicated by the arrow in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Darwin’s Tubercle

options.label: B
options.text: Preauricular Tag

options.label: C
options.text: Coloboma of Pinna

options.label: D
options.text: Keloid

questions.correct_answer: A. Darwin’s Tubercle
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Darwin’s Tubercle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Darwin’s Tubercle is a normal anatomical variant appearing as a small, pointed prominence on the upper helix, representing a vestigial remnant from evolutionary development. It has no clinical significance and does not require treatment.
  • ➤ Darwin’s Tubercle is a normal anatomical variant appearing as a small, pointed prominence on the upper helix, representing a vestigial remnant from evolutionary development.
  • ➤ It has no clinical significance and does not require treatment.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the ENT clinic for evaluation of an abnormally shaped ear noticed at birth. Examination reveals that the helix is flat, and the upper crus of the antihelix is duplicated, reaching the rim of the helix. Based on the clinical image, what is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Stahl’s Ear

options.label: B
options.text: Cryptotia

options.label: C
options.text: Lop Ear

options.label: D
options.text: Microtia

questions.correct_answer: A. Stahl’s Ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stahl’s Ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stahl’s Ear is a congenital auricular deformity caused by abnormal folding of the antihelical cartilage, leading to a pointed or elfin-shaped ear. Early detection allows molding therapy within the first 6 weeks of life, while surgical correction may be needed later if untreated.
  • ➤ Stahl’s Ear is a congenital auricular deformity caused by abnormal folding of the antihelical cartilage, leading to a pointed or elfin-shaped ear.
  • ➤ Early detection allows molding therapy within the first 6 weeks of life, while surgical correction may be needed later if untreated.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 48

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with severe right ear pain and persistent otorrhea for the past two weeks. He reports that the pain is worse at night and does not improve with over-the-counter analgesics. Examination reveals tenderness over the external auditory canal (EAC), granulation tissue at the cartilaginous-bony junction, and cranial nerve VII weakness (right-sided facial palsy). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start intravenous ciprofloxacin and obtain imaging

options.label: B
options.text: Prescribe oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and schedule follow-up

options.label: C
options.text: Perform immediate surgical debridement of the external auditory canal

options.label: D
options.text: Start topical antibiotic ear drops and oral corticosteroids

questions.correct_answer: A. Start intravenous ciprofloxacin and obtain imaging
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Start Intravenous Ciprofloxacin and Obtain Imaging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is a life-threatening Pseudomonas infection seen in elderly diabetics, characterized by severe otalgia, persistent otorrhea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and possible cranial nerve palsies. Management includes IV ciprofloxacin, diabetes control, and prolonged antibiotic therapy (6–8 weeks).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic otitis externa presents to the clinic complaining of persistent ear discharge and hearing loss. He has a history of frequent cotton swab use for ear cleaning. Examination reveals copious purulent discharge in the external auditory canal, and the tympanic membrane is not visible. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe Oral Antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Perform aural toilet

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate referral for surgical intervention

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate topical antifungal therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform aural toilet
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perform Aural Toilet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aural toilet is the essential first step in managing chronic otitis externa with significant discharge. It allows for proper examination, diagnosis, and effective delivery of topical treatments. Oral antibiotics can be given next and surgery is reserved for complicated or refractory cases.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a one-week history of itching and fullness in her right ear. She reports no pain but mentions a slight hearing reduction. She has a history of swimming regularly. On examination, the external auditory canal is erythematous and has black-headed filamentous debris. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Which microorganism is most commonly responsible for this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Aspergillus Niger

options.label: B
options.text: Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

options.label: C
options.text: Candida Albicans

options.label: D
options.text: Staphylococcus Aureus

questions.correct_answer: A. Aspergillus Niger
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillus Niger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger is the most common cause of otomycosis, a fungal infection of the external auditory canal. It presents with itching, ear fullness, and black-headed filamentous fungal debris, particularly in individuals with frequent swimming exposure. Management includes aural toilet and topical antifungal therapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with acute onset of right-sided facial paralysis, severe ear pain, and a vesicular rash in his right ear. He also reports some hearing loss and vertigo on the same side. His past medical history is significant for chickenpox in childhood. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bell's Palsy

options.label: B
options.text: Acute Otitis Media

options.label: C
options.text: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Acoustic Neuroma

questions.correct_answer: C. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) is caused by reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and a vesicular rash in the ear or oral mucosa. It can also involve the vestibulocochlear nerve, causing hearing loss and vertigo. Early treatment with antivirals and corticosteroids improves outcomes.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents to the clinic with impacted cerumen. During the consultation, the resident explains about the glands in the external auditory canal (EAC) that contribute to cerumen production. Which type of glands predominantly contribute to the production of cerumen in the EAC?

options.label: A
options.text: Eccrine Sweat Glands

options.label: B
options.text: Sebaceous Glands

options.label: C
options.text: Apocrine Sweat Glands

options.label: D
options.text: Salivary Glands

questions.correct_answer: C. Apocrine Sweat Glands
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Apocrine Sweat Glands

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerumen (earwax) is primarily produced by apocrine sweat glands in the external auditory canal, with a minor contribution from sebaceous glands. It plays a protective role by preventing infections, trapping foreign particles, and lubricating the ear canal.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 53.

questions.text: During an otoscopic examination, a physician prepares to examine a 30-year-old adult patient's ear. What is the appropriate direction to pull the pinna for optimal visualization of the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: Straight forward

options.label: B
options.text: Downward and forward

options.label: C
options.text: Upward and backward

options.label: D
options.text: Upward and forward

questions.correct_answer: C. Upward and backward
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Upward and Backward

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For an otoscopic examination in adults, the pinna should be pulled upward and backward to straighten the external auditory canal, ensuring optimal visualization of the tympanic membrane. In children under 3 years, the pinna should be pulled downward and forward due to anatomical differences in the ear canal.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with ear pain and decreased hearing in his left ear. On clinical examination, the physician intends to thoroughly evaluate the external auditory canal (EAC). Which of the following findings would be most concerning when examining the EAC?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of cerumen

options.label: B
options.text: Bony protrusions along the canal wall

options.label: C
options.text: Granulation tissue at the floor of the canal

options.label: D
options.text: Slight erythema of the canal skin

questions.correct_answer: C. Granulation tissue at the floor of the canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Granulation Tissue at the Floor of the Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granulation tissue in the external auditory canal is a red flag that may indicate chronic infection (malignant otitis externa), cholesteatoma, or malignancy. Further evaluation with otoscopy, imaging, and biopsy is warranted in suspicious cases.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

questions.text: A medical student is learning about ear anatomy during an otolaryngology rotation. The attending physician points out a narrow region in the external auditory canal (EAC) and explains that this area can sometimes obstruct the view of the tympanic membrane during an otoscopic examination. Which part of the EAC is being described, and what is its significance?

options.label: A
options.text: The lateral third, consisting of cartilage, allows for flexibility during examination.

options.label: B
options.text: The isthmus, the narrowest part of the EAC, can limit visualization of the tympanic membrane.

options.label: C
options.text: The medial two-thirds, made of bone, provide protection to deeper structures.

options.label: D
options.text: The junction where the bony and cartilaginous parts meet, often the site of cerumen impaction.

questions.correct_answer: B. The isthmus, the narrowest part of the EAC, can limit visualization of the tympanic membrane.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The isthmus, the narrowest part of the EAC, can limit visualization of the tympanic membrane.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal and can limit tympanic membrane visualization during otoscopy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections involving both the parotid gland and the external auditory canal. Which anatomical feature is most likely facilitating the spread of infection between these two regions?

options.label: A
options.text: Eustachian Tube Dysfunction

options.label: B
options.text: Fissures of Santorini

options.label: C
options.text: Mastoid Air Cells involvement

options.label: D
options.text: Tympanic Membrane Perforation

questions.correct_answer: B. Fissures of Santorini
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fissures of Santorini

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fissures of Santorini in the cartilaginous external auditory canal allow infection to spread between the EAC and the parotid gland.

questions.text: A medical resident is learning about the anatomy of the external auditory canal (EAC) during an otolaryngology rotation. The attending physician explains the division of the EAC and its clinical importance. Which of the following correctly describes the division of the external auditory canal?

options.label: A
options.text: The outer one-third is bony and lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands, while the inner two-thirds is cartilaginous and lacks these structures.

options.label: B
options.text: The entire EAC is cartilaginous and lined with skin containing hair follicles and ceruminous glands.

options.label: C
options.text: The outer one-third is cartilaginous and lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands, while the inner two-thirds is bony and lacks these structures.

options.label: D
options.text: The EAC is divided into equal bony and cartilaginous halves, both lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands.

questions.correct_answer: C. The outer one-third is cartilaginous and lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands, while the inner two-thirds is bony and lacks these structures.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The outer one-third is cartilaginous and lined with hair follicles and ceruminous glands, while the inner two-thirds is bony and lacks these structures.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The external auditory canal is divided into an outer cartilaginous third, which contains hair follicles and ceruminous glands, and an inner bony two-thirds, which lacks these structures. This anatomical knowledge is crucial for understanding ear pathology and clinical management.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with acute onset of severe pain in her left ear. She denies any history of trauma or infection. On examination, she experiences intense pain when the anterior wall of the external auditory canal (EAC) is gently palpated. Which nerve is most likely responsible for the innervation of this area of the EAC?

options.label: A
options.text: The Auriculo-Temporal Nerve

options.label: B
options.text: The Greater Auricular Nerve

options.label: C
options.text: The Vagus Nerve

options.label: D
options.text: The Facial Nerve

questions.correct_answer: A. The Auriculo-Temporal Nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The Auriculo-Temporal Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory innervation to the anterior wall of the external auditory canal (EAC). Understanding the nerve supply is essential for diagnosing and managing ear pain.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 4.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic with a two-day history of severe pain in her right ear. She reports a sensation of fullness and decreased hearing on the affected side. On examination, the External Auditory Canal (EAC) is noted to be swollen with a visible red, tender nodule near the outer third. There is no discharge or tympanic membrane perforation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute otitis externa

options.label: B
options.text: Eustachian tube dysfunction

options.label: C
options.text: Furuncle of the external auditory canal

options.label: D
options.text: Cholesteatoma

questions.correct_answer: C. Furuncle of the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Furuncle of the External Auditory Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A furuncle of the external auditory canal is a localized infection of a hair follicle, presenting as a painful, red, swollen nodule in the canal, often associated with severe pain and a sensation of fullness. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus, and the tragal sign is positive.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 51-52.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of right ear pain, itching, and hearing loss. He reports swimming in a lake over the weekend. On examination, the external auditory canal (EAC) is erythematous, edematous, and there is scant purulent discharge. The tympanic membrane is not clearly visible due to swelling. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Topical antibiotic drops with a corticosteroid

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate tympanostomy tube placement

options.label: D
options.text: Systemic antifungal therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Topical antibiotic drops with a corticosteroid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Topical antibiotic drops with a corticosteroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial treatment for diffuse otitis externa, especially following water exposure, involves topical antibiotic drops combined with corticosteroids to treat the infection and reduce inflammation in the ear canal.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent ear itching, discomfort, and decreased hearing in his right ear. He denies any significant past medical history. On examination, the external auditory canal (EAC) is noted to be filled with blackish debris. The tympanic membrane is not clearly visible due to the debris. Otoscopic examination reveals no signs of inflammation or bacterial infection. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

options.label: B
options.text: Aspergillus Niger

options.label: C
options.text: Candida Albicans

options.label: D
options.text: Staphylococcus Aureus

questions.correct_answer: B. Aspergillus Niger
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergillus Niger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus Niger is a common fungal pathogen responsible for otomycosis, presenting with blackish debris in the external auditory canal and symptoms such as ear itching, discomfort, and decreased hearing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic patient presents with severe ear pain, otorrhea, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal. The patient is diagnosed with malignant otitis externa. Which organism is most commonly responsible for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

options.label: B
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus

options.label: C
options.text: Aspergillus niger

options.label: D
options.text: Streptococcus pneumoniae

questions.correct_answer: A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas Aeruginosa is the most common organism responsible for malignant otitis externa, especially in diabetic patients and those with compromised immune systems. Early identification and treatment are critical to prevent complications such as skull base involvement.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with severe right ear pain, discharge, and granulation tissue in the external auditory canal (EAC). He was treated for otitis externa two weeks ago, but his symptoms have worsened. The physician is concerned about the possibility of malignant otitis externa extending into the skull base. Which imaging modality is most appropriate to assess the extent of his infection?

options.label: A
options.text: CT scan of the temporal bone

options.label: B
options.text: MRI of the head and neck

options.label: C
options.text: Gallium 67 scan

options.label: D
options.text: Plain radiography of the skull

questions.correct_answer: C. Gallium 67 scan
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gallium 67 scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Gallium 67 scan is a highly sensitive imaging modality that helps detect and monitor the extent of infection in malignant otitis externa, especially in diabetic or immunocompromised patients.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with poorly controlled diabetes presents with symptoms suggestive of malignant otitis externa. The physician considers further imaging to assess the extent of the disease. What is the primary role of a Technetium-99m scan in this clinical scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the causative organism

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate the extent of bone involvement

options.label: C
options.text: To assess the function of the Eustachian tube

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the presence of middle ear effusion

questions.correct_answer: B. To evaluate the extent of bone involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) To evaluate the extent of bone involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of malignant otitis externa, the Technetium-99m scan is used to evaluate bone involvement and detect osteomyelitis, which is a severe complication affecting the temporal bone and skull base.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic history of right ear pain, hearing loss, and occasional discharge. She denies any history of swimming or trauma to the ear. On examination, the external auditory canal (EAC) is filled with compacted keratinous material. The tympanic membrane is not visible due to the obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Cerumen Impaction

options.label: B
options.text: Cholesteatoma

options.label: C
options.text: Keratosis Obturans

options.label: D
options.text: Otitis Externa

questions.correct_answer: C. Keratosis Obturans
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Keratosis Obturans

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keratosis Obturans is characterized by the accumulation of compacted keratinous material in the external auditory canal, leading to symptoms like pain, hearing loss, and occasional discharge, without a history of frequent water exposure or trauma.
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 55
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 55

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with severe ear pain and swelling in his right ear for the past 3 days. He also reports tenderness while chewing and touching the external ear. On examination, there is a localized, erythematous swelling in the outer third of the external auditory canal. There is no purulent discharge, and the tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute otitis externa (diffuse type)

options.label: B
options.text: Furuncle of the external auditory canal

options.label: C
options.text: Cholesteatoma

options.label: D
options.text: Acute otitis media

questions.correct_answer: B. Furuncle of the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Furuncle of the External Auditory Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Furuncles (localized staphylococcal infections) occur in the outer one-third of the external auditory canal because hair follicles are only present in this region. They present with severe localized pain and tenderness, and management includes warm compresses, antibiotics, and incision and drainage if necessary.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with persistent cough and irritation whenever he cleans his ears with a cotton swab. He denies any fever, respiratory symptoms, or recent infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a normal external auditory canal and tympanic membrane. Which of the following nerves is responsible for this reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

options.label: B
options.text: Auriculotemporal nerve (Branch of CN V3)

options.label: C
options.text: Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold’s nerve, CN X)

options.label: D
options.text: Facial nerve (CN VII)

questions.correct_answer: C. Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold’s nerve, CN X)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Auricular Branch of the Vagus Nerve (Arnold’s Nerve, CN X)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold’s nerve, CN X) innervates the posterior wall and floor of the external auditory canal. Stimulation of this nerve can trigger the Arnold’s Reflex (ear-cough reflex) due to vagal involvement in the respiratory tract.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the clinic for evaluation of right-sided congenital hearing loss. On examination, there is absence of the external auditory canal on the right side, while the auricle is normally developed. Which of the following best explains the embryological basis of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of the first branchial arch to form properly

options.label: B
options.text: Incomplete recanalization of the meatal plug

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of the second branchial cleft to regress

options.label: D
options.text: Improper fusion of the hillocks of His

questions.correct_answer: B. Incomplete recanalization of the meatal plug
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Incomplete Recanalization of the Meatal Plug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The external auditory canal develops from the first branchial cleft. It initially forms as a meatal plug, which later recanalizes to form the bony canal lining. Failure of this recanalization results in congenital aural atresia, where the deeper canal may develop, but the outer part remains atretic.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 12

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the ENT clinic with recurrent swelling and discharge from a small opening just below and behind the angle of the mandible. His parents report that the swelling and discharge worsen during upper respiratory infections. On examination, there is a small pit in the external auditory canal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Empirical antibiotic therapy and observation

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical excision of the fistula

options.label: C
options.text: Fine needle aspiration (FNA) of the swelling

options.label: D
options.text: Incision and drainage of the fistula tract

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgical excision of the fistula
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Surgical Excision of the Fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A collaural fistula is an abnormal first branchial cleft anomaly that presents as a persistent tract between the external auditory canal and the upper neck (below and behind the angle of the mandible). It requires surgical excision to prevent recurrent infections, with caution due to its proximity to the facial nerve.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 50,51

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with severe right ear pain and tenderness for the past 3 days. He reports that the pain worsens with jaw movements (chewing) and when touching his ear. Examination reveals a small, erythematous, tender swelling in the outer third of the external auditory canal. There is no otorrhea, and the tympanic membrane appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute Otitis Media

options.label: B
options.text: Acute Diffuse Otitis Externa

options.label: C
options.text: Furuncle of the External Auditory Canal

options.label: D
options.text: Cholesteatoma

questions.correct_answer: C. Furuncle of the External Auditory Canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Furuncle of the External Auditory Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Furuncles (localized acute otitis externa) occur due to Staphylococcus aureus infection of hair follicles in the outer third of the external auditory canal. They present with severe pain, tenderness, and localized swelling. Management includes systemic antibiotics, analgesics, and warm compresses, with incision and drainage if an abscess forms.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with severe right ear pain, itching, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. He recently returned from a vacation where he went swimming daily. He denies fever or upper respiratory symptoms. Examination reveals an erythematous, swollen external auditory canal with purulent discharge. The tympanic membrane is not clearly visible due to canal swelling, and manipulation of the pinna elicits pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe oral amoxicillin-clavulanate

options.label: B
options.text: Perform ear toilet and insert a medicated wick

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribe oral antifungals

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate surgical drainage of the external auditory canal

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform ear toilet and insert a medicated wick
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perform Ear Toilet and Insert a Medicated Wick

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse otitis externa (swimmer’s ear) is a bacterial infection of the external auditory canal, commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. The first step in management is ear toilet (cleaning of the canal), followed by insertion of a medicated wick with antibiotic-steroid drops. Systemic antibiotics are only needed for cellulitis or systemic symptoms.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51,52

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with intense ear itching, a feeling of fullness, and mild discomfort in her right ear. She also reports watery discharge with a musty odor. She denies fever, hearing loss, or recent illness but mentions using topical antibiotic ear drops for a prior ear infection. Otoscopic examination reveals a black-headed filamentous growth in the external auditory canal. The tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

options.label: A
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus

options.label: B
options.text: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

options.label: C
options.text: Aspergillus niger

options.label: D
options.text: Streptococcus pyogenes

questions.correct_answer: C. Aspergillus niger
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspergillus niger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otomycosis (fungal otitis externa) is caused by Aspergillus niger (black-headed filamentous growth) or Candida albicans (white, creamy debris). It presents with intense itching, watery discharge with a musty odor, and ear fullness. Treatment involves thorough ear toilet and topical antifungal therapy (clotrimazole, nystatin, or salicylic acid in alcohol).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with intense ear itching, irritation, and mild discomfort in her right ear for the past one week. She denies fever or pain but mentions that she recently used topical neomycin ear drops for a prior ear infection. Examination reveals erythematous, swollen external auditory canal skin with vesicles, oozing, and crusting. There is no purulent discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue topical neomycin drops and observe

options.label: B
options.text: Prescribe oral antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Discontinue neomycin drops and apply a topical steroid cream

options.label: D
options.text: Perform surgical debridement of the ear canal

questions.correct_answer: C. Discontinue neomycin drops and apply a topical steroid cream
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Discontinue Neomycin Drops and Apply a Topical Steroid Cream

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eczematous otitis externa is a hypersensitivity reaction, often triggered by topical antibiotics like neomycin. It presents with intense itching, erythema, vesicle formation, oozing, and crusting. Management includes discontinuation of the offending agent and application of topical steroid cream to reduce inflammation.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with persistent ear itching and flaky skin around his ear. He also reports mild irritation but no significant pain or hearing loss. On examination, greasy yellow scales are noted in the external auditory canal, lobule, and postauricular sulcus. He also has flaky skin on his scalp. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe oral antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Perform aggressive ear debridement

options.label: C
options.text: Apply a cream containing salicylic acid and sulfur

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe antifungal ear drops

questions.correct_answer: C. Apply a cream containing salicylic acid and sulfur
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Apply a Cream Containing Salicylic Acid and Sulfur

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Seborrheic otitis externa is a chronic inflammatory condition associated with seborrheic dermatitis. It presents with ear itching and greasy yellow scales in the external auditory canal and postauricular region. Management includes gentle cleaning and topical creams containing salicylic acid and sulfur.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the clinic with intense itching of her right ear for the past several weeks. She reports that she frequently scratches her ear to relieve the itching. There is no ear pain, discharge, or hearing loss. Examination reveals excoriation marks and mild erythema on the external auditory canal and pinna. There is no fungal debris or purulent discharge. The rest of the ENT examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe topical antibiotic-steroid ear drops

options.label: B
options.text: Recommend sympathetic psychotherapy and apply an ear pack

options.label: C
options.text: Perform immediate ear debridement and irrigation

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe antifungal therapy for suspected otomycosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Recommend sympathetic psychotherapy and apply an ear pack
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Recommend Sympathetic Psychotherapy and Apply an Ear Pack

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neurodermatitis of the external ear is caused by compulsive scratching due to psychological factors. It presents with intense itching, excoriation marks, and mild erythema. Management includes sympathetic psychotherapy, protective ear packing, and treatment for any secondary infection if present.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with persistent right ear pain and purulent otorrhea for the past several months. He denies hearing loss or vertigo. Otoscopic examination reveals granulation tissue and exposed bone in the external auditory canal (EAC), with a normal tympanic membrane. There is no history of recent infection, but he underwent ear surgery several years ago. A biopsy is planned to rule out malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Malignant otitis externa

options.label: B
options.text: Primary cholesteatoma of the external auditory canal

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with cholesteatoma

options.label: D
options.text: External ear carcinoma

questions.correct_answer: B. Primary cholesteatoma of the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary Cholesteatoma of the External Auditory Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary cholesteatoma of the external auditory canal is a rare condition where squamous epithelium invades the bony external canal, often after trauma or surgery. It presents with persistent otorrhea, pain, and granulation tissue, with a normal tympanic membrane. Management involves surgical removal of necrotic bone and histopathological evaluation to rule out malignancy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 53

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with progressive right ear fullness and mild conductive hearing loss. He denies pain, discharge, or recurrent infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a single, smooth, pedunculated, bony-hard mass arising from the posterior wall of the external auditory canal (EAC) near its outer end. The tympanic membrane is intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Exostosis

options.label: B
options.text: Osteoma of the External Auditory Canal

options.label: C
options.text: Cholesteatoma

options.label: D
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the external ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Osteoma of the External Auditory Canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteoma of the External Auditory Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteomas of the external auditory canal are benign, pedunculated bony tumors arising from cancellous bone, typically presenting as single, smooth masses on the posterior wall of the osseous canal near its outer end. They are usually asymptomatic but may require surgical removal if they cause conductive hearing loss or canal obstruction.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 107.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with gradual hearing loss and occasional ear blockage. He has a history of frequent cold-water exposure due to surfing. Examination reveals multiple smooth, sessile bony swellings in the deeper part of the external auditory canal near the tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Osteoma of the External Auditory Canal

options.label: B
options.text: Exostoses ("Surfer’s Ear")

options.label: C
options.text: Cholesteatoma

options.label: D
options.text: Malignant Otitis Externa

questions.correct_answer: B. Exostoses ("Surfer’s Ear")
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Exostoses ("Surfer’s Ear")

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exostoses ("Surfer’s Ear") are multiple, bilateral, sessile bony growths in the deep external auditory canal, commonly seen in individuals with repeated cold-water exposure. Management is conservative if asymptomatic; surgical removal is indicated if they cause hearing loss or recurrent wax impaction.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 107

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with gradual hearing loss and a sensation of ear fullness in his right ear. He denies pain, discharge, or a history of infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a smooth, firm, skin-covered polypoid swelling in the outer part of the external auditory canal (EAC), attached to the posterior wall. The lesion is non-tender, and there is accumulation of cerumen and debris due to obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Exostosis

options.label: B
options.text: Ceruminoma

options.label: C
options.text: Cholesteatoma

options.label: D
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the external ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Ceruminoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ceruminoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ceruminomas are tumors of ceruminous glands in the external auditory canal, presenting as smooth, firm, skin-covered polypoid swellings that can cause obstruction and cerumen retention. Management includes wide surgical excision, histological evaluation, and postoperative radiotherapy if malignancy is suspected.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 107

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a painless, slow-growing mass in his right external auditory canal (EAC). He denies hearing loss, ear discharge, or recent infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a smooth, skin-covered swelling in the outer part of the meatus. The lesion is non-tender and does not involve the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Exostosis

options.label: B
options.text: Sebaceous Adenoma

options.label: C
options.text: Ceruminoma

options.label: D
options.text: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the External Ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Sebaceous Adenoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sebaceous Adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sebaceous adenomas are benign tumors of sebaceous glands in the external auditory canal, presenting as smooth, skin-covered swellings in the outer meatus. The treatment of choice is surgical excision, followed by histopathological evaluation to confirm diagnosis and rule out malignancy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 108

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic ear discharge presents with blood-stained otorrhea and severe ear pain for the past few weeks. He has also noticed progressive facial weakness on the affected side. Otoscopic examination reveals an ulcerated lesion with granulation tissue and a friable, bleeding polypoid mass in the external auditory canal. Regional lymph nodes are enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media with granulation tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Malignant otitis externa

options.label: C
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the external auditory canal

options.label: D
options.text: Ceruminoma

questions.correct_answer: C. Squamous cell carcinoma of the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the External Auditory Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the external auditory canal presents with chronic ear discharge that becomes blood-stained, severe otalgia, an ulcerated or polypoid bleeding mass, and possible facial nerve paralysis. Management involves en bloc surgical excision followed by postoperative radiotherapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 108

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a painless ulcerated lesion on the posterior wall of his right external auditory canal. He has no history of chronic ear infections or discharge but has had progressive lesion growth over the past six months. On examination, the lesion appears slow-growing, pearly, and non-healing, with rolled edges and mild surface telangiectasia. There is no facial nerve involvement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the external auditory canal

options.label: B
options.text: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the external auditory canal

options.label: C
options.text: Malignant otitis externa

options.label: D
options.text: Exostosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) of the External Auditory Canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the external auditory canal presents as a slow-growing, ulcerated lesion with rolled edges and surface telangiectasia. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and management involves wide surgical excision with postoperative radiotherapy if necessary.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 108

questions.text: During an otoscopic examination, a medical student observes the tympanic membrane (TM) of a patient. The attending physician asks the student to identify the landmark that appears as a triangular, light-reflecting area on the TM. Which part of the tympanic membrane does this describe?

options.label: A
options.text: The pars flaccida

options.label: B
options.text: The umbo

options.label: C
options.text: The cone of light

options.label: D
options.text: The pars tensa

questions.correct_answer: C. The cone of light
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The cone of light

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cone of light is the light-reflecting area seen on the tympanic membrane during otoscopic examination, which helps in orienting the examiner to the TM's anatomy.
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg2
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg2

questions.text: A medical student is studying the anatomy of the ear and learns about the layers of the tympanic membrane (TM). Which of the following correctly lists the layers of the TM from outermost to innermost?

options.label: A
options.text: Squamous epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Mucous membrane, Fibrous layer, Squamous epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane, Squamous epithelium

options.label: D
options.text: Squamous epithelium, Mucous membrane, Fibrous layer

questions.correct_answer: A. Squamous epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squamous Epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The anatomical layering of the tympanic membrane consists of an outer stratified squamous epithelial layer , a middle fibrous layer , and an inner mucous membrane layer . This knowledge is important for understanding various ear pathologies and their treatments .
  • ➤ anatomical layering
  • ➤ tympanic membrane
  • ➤ outer stratified squamous epithelial layer
  • ➤ middle fibrous layer
  • ➤ an inner mucous membrane layer
  • ➤ ear pathologies
  • ➤ their treatments
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg3
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg3

questions.text: A medical student is learning about the anatomy of the tympanic membrane (TM). The attending physician asks the student to identify the part of the TM that is prone to atelectasis and cholesteatoma formation. Which part of the tympanic membrane is being described?

options.label: A
options.text: The pars flaccida

options.label: B
options.text: The pars tensa

options.label: C
options.text: The umbo

options.label: D
options.text: The annulus

questions.correct_answer: A. The pars flaccida
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The pars flaccida

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The pars flaccida (Shrapnell's membrane) of the tympanic membrane is more prone to atelectasis and cholesteatoma formation due to its less robust structure compared to the pars tensa.
  • ➤ more prone to atelectasis
  • ➤ cholesteatoma formation
  • ➤ less robust structure
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg2
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg2

questions.text: A resident is performing an otoscopic examination on a patient and explains the anatomy of the tympanic membrane (TM) to a medical student. The resident points out a fibrous ring that holds the TM in place. Which part of the tympanic membrane's anatomy is being described?

options.label: A
options.text: The Pars Tensa

options.label: B
options.text: The Pars Flaccida

options.label: C
options.text: The Annulus Tympanicus

options.label: D
options.text: The Umbo

questions.correct_answer: C. The Annulus Tympanicus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The Annulus Tympanicus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The annulus tympanicus is the fibrous ring that anchors the tympanic membrane to the bony external auditory canal, providing structural support to the TM.
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 2
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 2

questions.text: During an otoscopic examination of a patient complaining of muffled hearing, a physician observes a retracted tympanic membrane. Which of the following findings is most indicative of a retracted tympanic membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: Bulging of the tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Visible bony landmarks and a prominent malleus handle

options.label: C
options.text: Perforation in the central part of the tympanic membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Fluid level behind the tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Visible bony landmarks and a prominent malleus handle
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Visible bony landmarks and a prominent malleus handle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Retracted tympanic membrane is characterized by visible bony landmarks of the middle ear and a more prominent-looking malleus handle, due to negative pressure in the middle ear.
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg55
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg55

questions.text: In the anatomy of the tympanic membrane, the middle fibrous layer is characterized by a specific arrangement of fibers. How are the fibers arranged in the middle layer of the tympanic membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: Exclusively radially arranged fibers

options.label: B
options.text: Exclusively circularly arranged fibers

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of radial, circular, and parabolic fibers

options.label: D
options.text: Predominantly parabolic fibers with minimal radial and circular arrangement

questions.correct_answer: C. A combination of radial, circular, and parabolic fibers
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A combination of radial, circular, and parabolic fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The middle layer of the tympanic membrane contains a combination of radial, circular, and parabolic fibers, contributing to its strength, resilience, and conical shape for effective sound transmission.
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg4
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg4

questions.text: A medical student is learning about the innervation of the tympanic membrane. Which nerve is responsible for the sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: Auriculotemporal nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Vagus nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Glossopharyngeal nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Facial nerve

questions.correct_answer: A. Auriculotemporal nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Auriculotemporal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The sensory innervation of the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane is provided by the auriculotemporal nerve , a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) .
  • ➤ outer anterior half
  • ➤ auriculotemporal nerve
  • ➤ mandibular nerve (V3),
  • ➤ trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V)
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg4
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg4

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with acute onset of severe ear pain and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals multiple blisters on the tympanic membrane. This presentation is most consistent with which of the following conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Myringitis bullosa

options.label: B
options.text: Acute otitis media

options.label: C
options.text: Cholesteatoma

options.label: D
options.text: Tympanic membrane perforation

questions.correct_answer: A. Myringitis bullosa
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Myringitis bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Myringitis bullosa is a condition characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane, often associated with severe ear pain and temporary hearing loss, and commonly seen in the context of viral infections.
  • ➤ Myringitis bullosa
  • ➤ presence of vesicles
  • ➤ blisters
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg55
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg55

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with otorrhea. Otoscopic examination reveals granulation tissue on the tympanic membrane without any vesicles or blisters. Which condition does this presentation most likely indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Myringitis Granulosa

options.label: B
options.text: Acute Otitis Externa

options.label: C
options.text: Bullous Myringitis

options.label: D
options.text: Tympanic Membrane Perforation

questions.correct_answer: A. Myringitis Granulosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Myringitis Granulosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Myringitis Granulosa as a condition characterized by the presence of granulation tissue on the tympanic membrane, typically associated with chronic inflammatory processes of the middle ear .
  • ➤ presence of granulation tissue
  • ➤ chronic inflammatory processes
  • ➤ middle ear
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg55
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg55

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent otitis media during childhood. Otoscopic examination reveals white, chalky plaques on the tympanic membrane. Which condition is most consistent with this finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Tympanosclerosis

options.label: B
options.text: Acute otitis media

options.label: C
options.text: Bullous myringitis

options.label: D
options.text: Tympanic membrane perforation

questions.correct_answer: A. Tympanosclerosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tympanosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tympanosclerosis is characterized by the presence of white, chalky plaques on the tympanic membrane, often resulting from chronic inflammation such as repeated episodes of otitis media.
  • ➤ presence of white, chalky plaques
  • ➤ chronic inflammation
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg56
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg56

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of muffled hearing in her right ear. She has a history of recurrent otitis media in childhood but no recent infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a retracted right tympanic membrane, with the fibrous annulus becoming more prominent. The cone of light is missing, and the lateral process of the malleus is prominent due to the medialized handle of the malleus. There is no contact with the ossicles or any signs of ossicular erosion. According to Sade's classification, which stage of pars tensa retraction does this patient's condition correspond to?

options.label: A
options.text: Grade I

options.label: B
options.text: Grade II

options.label: C
options.text: Grade III

options.label: D
options.text: Grade IV

questions.correct_answer: A. Grade I
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Grade I

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grade I pars tensa retraction according to Sade's classification , characterized by slight retraction , a more prominent fibrous annulus , absence of the cone of light , and a prominent lateral process of the malleus due to the medialized handle of the malleus , with no contact with the ossicles or signs of ossicular erosion.
  • ➤ Grade I pars tensa retraction
  • ➤ Sade's classification
  • ➤ slight retraction
  • ➤ prominent fibrous annulus
  • ➤ absence of the cone of light
  • ➤ prominent lateral process of the malleus
  • ➤ medialized handle of the malleus

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with hearing loss and intermittent ear fullness in her left ear. She has a history of recurrent ear infections during her childhood. Otoscopic examination reveals a retracted pars flaccida that is adherent to the neck of the malleus without any visible air space behind the retraction pocket. Based on Tos's classification of pars flaccida retraction, which of the following best describes the patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: TYPE 0

options.label: B
options.text: TYPE I

options.label: C
options.text: TYPE II

options.label: D
options.text: TYPE III

questions.correct_answer: C. TYPE II
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type II pars flaccida retraction according to Tos's classification , characterized by retraction and adherence to the neck of the malleus without any visible air space behind the retraction pocket.
  • ➤ Type II pars flaccida retraction
  • ➤ Tos's classification
  • ➤ retraction and adherence to the neck of the malleus

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the otolaryngology clinic by his parents for evaluation of recurrent acute otitis media. The otolaryngologist decides to perform myringotomy with tube insertion to prevent further episodes and alleviate the child's symptoms. Which of the following instruments is most appropriate for making the initial incision in the tympanic membrane during this procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: Rosen needle

options.label: B
options.text: Hartmann forceps

options.label: C
options.text: Myringotome

options.label: D
options.text: Alligator forceps

questions.correct_answer: C. Myringotome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Myringotome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringotome is the appropriate instrument for making the initial incision in the tympanic membrane during myringotomy procedures , due to its specific design for precise and controlled incisions.
  • ➤ Myringotome
  • ➤ appropriate instrument for making the initial incision
  • ➤ tympanic membrane
  • ➤ myringotomy procedures

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the middle ear cleft?

options.label: A
options.text: Eustachian tube

options.label: B
options.text: Mastoid air cells

options.label: C

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the lateral wall of the middle ear is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is formed by the round window

options.label: B
options.text: Scutum is located on the medial wall of the middle ear

options.label: C
options.text: Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: Scutum is part of the posterior wall of the middle ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral wall of the middle ear is formed by the tympanic membrane and the scutum, which is often eroded in cholesteatoma.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the posterior wall of the middle ear is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Chorda tympani nerve arises above the level of the facial nerve in the middle ear and exits via the facial recess

options.label: B
options.text: Facial recess is located between the incus and facial nerve, with the stapes forming its roof

options.label: C
options.text: The stapedius muscle arises from the pyramid and inserts into the anterior crus of the stapes

options.label: D
options.text: The facial nerve gives off the chorda tympani below the middle ear and runs vertically in the posterior wall

questions.correct_answer: D. The facial nerve gives off the chorda tympani below the middle ear and runs vertically in the posterior wall
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The facial nerve gives off the chorda tympani below the middle ear and runs vertically in the posterior wall

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve runs vertically in the posterior wall of the middle ear and gives off the chorda tympani below the cavity, which travels upward between the malleus and incus and exits via the canal of Huguier; the stapedius muscle arises from the pyramid and inserts on the posterior crus of the stapes, and the facial recess lies between the chorda tympani and facial nerve with the incus short process forming its superior boundary.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes MacEwen’s triangle, a key surgical landmark in mastoid surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it

options.label: B
options.text: It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus

options.label: C
options.text: It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

options.label: D
options.text: It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube

questions.correct_answer: C. It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MacEwen’s triangle is a surface landmark bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, temporal line, and a posterior tangent to the external canal, used to identify the mastoid antrum located approximately 1.5 cm deep to it.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5,6
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5,6

questions.text: How is the stapes footplate attached to the oval window of the cochlea?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery

options.label: C
options.text: Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: B. By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery

  • ➤ The stapes footplate is attached to the oval window via the annular ligament in a circumferential manner, allowing sound transmission to the inner ear.

  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding stapedial otosclerosis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by bony overgrowth at the round window and primarily leads to sensorineural hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: It commonly presents in young white females and worsens during pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with Ehler-Danlos syndrome and characterized by red sclera

options.label: D
options.text: It most often affects elderly males and is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern

questions.correct_answer: B. It commonly presents in young white females and worsens during pregnancy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It commonly presents in young white females and worsens during pregnancy

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stapedial otosclerosis is caused by spongy bone deposition at the footplate and fissula ante fenestram, leading to conductive hearing loss and commonly affecting young white females, especially during pregnancy, with associations like blue sclera and autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss. She reports that she hears better in noisy environments. Otoscopy reveals an intact tympanic membrane with a reddish hue over the promontory. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media

options.label: B
options.text: Otosclerosis

options.label: C
options.text: Cochlear ototoxicity

options.label: D
options.text: Tympanosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Otosclerosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis presents with conductive hearing loss, intact TM, Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz, paracusis Willisi, and Schwartz sign; treatment of choice is stapedotomy.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86

questions.text: According to the Sade classification of tympanic membrane retraction, which of the following correctly describes Grade 3 retraction of the pars tensa?

options.label: A
options.text: Tympanic membrane is mildly retracted with prominence of the lateral process of the malleus

options.label: B
options.text: Tympanic membrane adheres to the ossicles (incus or stapes)

options.label: C
options.text: Tympanic membrane contacts the promontory

options.label: D
options.text: Tympanic membrane is plastered over ossicles and promontory with loss of aeration

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle and interpretation of the Stenger test in a patient suspected of feigning unilateral hearing loss?

Educational Objective:
