questions.text: A 45yr old female presented with gradual onset progressive hearing loss in the right ear associated with pulsatile tinnitus. The tympanic membrane appeared reddish. TFT showed Rinne was negative on the right side, positive on the left and Weber lateralised to the right. Tinnitus temporarily ceased with carotid pressure and auscultation over mastoid revealed an audible bruit. Most likely diagnosis:

options.label: A
options.text: ASOM

options.label: B
options.text: Glomus Jugulare

options.label: C
options.text: Acoustic Neuroma

options.label: D
options.text: Otosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Glomus Jugulare
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. ASOM (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media): This condition typically presents with rapid onset ear pain, fever, and hearing loss . The presentation of pulsatile tinnitus, a reddish tympanic membrane, and a bruit over the mastoid are not characteristic of ASOM.
  • • Option A. ASOM (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media):
  • • rapid onset
  • • ear pain, fever,
  • • hearing loss
  • • Option C. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): This is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII ( vestibulocochlear nerve ). It typically presents with gradual hearing loss and tinnitus but does not produce a reddish tympanic membrane or an audible bruit. Also, acoustic neuroma usually causes sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss.
  • • Option C. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma):
  • • benign tumor
  • • cranial nerve VIII
  • • vestibulocochlear nerve
  • • gradual hearing loss
  • • tinnitus
  • • sensorineural hearing loss,
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis: Here, conductive hearing loss with intact tympanic membrane is noted but tinnitus is seen in only few people. And tinnitus, if present, is not pulsatile. Aquino sign is not seen here.
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus jugulare in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss (as indicated by negative Rinne and lateralization of Weber to the affected side ), a reddish tympanic membrane , and an audible bruit over the mastoid .
  • ➤ Glomus jugulare
  • ➤ pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss
  • ➤ negative Rinne and lateralization of Weber
  • ➤ affected side
  • ➤ reddish tympanic membrane
  • ➤ audible bruit
  • ➤ mastoid
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss. Otoscopy reveals a reddish mass behind the intact tympanic membrane that blanches on applying pressure with Siegel’s speculum. Which of the following is true regarding her likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Biopsy is the investigation of choice to confirm glomus tympanicum

options.label: B
options.text: CT scan shows salt and pepper appearance due to tumor vascularity

options.label: C
options.text: Most glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines

options.label: D
options.text: The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

questions.correct_answer: D. The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus tympanicum is a highly vascular middle ear tumor arising from the promontory, often in females, presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, and is fed by the inferior tympanic branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery; biopsy is contraindicated.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of chronic ear infections and persistent conductive hearing loss. On examination, the otolaryngologist suspects ossicular chain disruption. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the anatomical order of the ossicles in the middle ear from the tympanic membrane to the oval window?

options.label: A
options.text: Incus, malleus, stapes

options.label: B
options.text: Stapes, incus, malleus

options.label: C
options.text: Malleus, incus, stapes

options.label: D
options.text: Stapes, malleus, incus

questions.correct_answer: C. Malleus, incus, stapes
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malleus, incus, stapes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Incus, malleus, stapes: This sequence is incorrect because the malleus, not the incus, is the first ossicle in the chain directly attached to the tympanic membrane.
  • • Option A. Incus, malleus, stapes:
  • • malleus, not the incus, is the first ossicle in the chain
  • • Option B. Stapes, incus, malleus: This sequence is incorrect as it reverses the actual anatomical order of the ossicles. The correct sequence starts with the malleus attached to the tympanic membrane and ends with the stapes at the oval window.
  • • Option B. Stapes, incus, malleus:
  • • reverses the actual anatomical order of the ossicles.
  • • Option D. Stapes, malleus, incus: This sequence is also incorrect because it does not follow the natural order of vibration transmission from the tympanic membrane to the oval window.
  • • Option D. Stapes, malleus, incus:
  • • does not follow the natural order of vibration transmission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct anatomical sequence of the ossicles in the middle ear is malleus , incus, stapes , which is essential for the transmission of sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the oval window .
  • ➤ correct anatomical sequence of the ossicles
  • ➤ middle ear is malleus
  • ➤ incus, stapes
  • ➤ transmission of sound vibrations
  • ➤ tympanic membrane
  • ➤ oval window

  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 24
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 24

questions.text: The audiogram shown reveals a bilateral high-frequency sloping sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Otosclerosis

options.label: B
options.text: Ménière’s disease

options.label: C
options.text: Presbycusis

options.label: D
options.text: Noise-induced hearing loss

questions.correct_answer: C. Presbycusis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Presbycusis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A bilateral high-frequency sloping sensorineural hearing loss on audiogram is characteristic of presbycusis.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 52
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 52

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the chorda tympani nerve is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a branch of glossopharyngeal nerve that enters the middle ear through the Eustachian tube

options.label: B
options.text: It runs lateral to the tympanic membrane between the incus and the stapes

options.label: C
options.text: It carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and taste fibres from posterior one-third of tongue

options.label: D
options.text: It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

questions.correct_answer: D. It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chorda tympani is a branch of facial nerve that carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and secretomotor fibres to submandibular/sublingual glands, running between the handle of malleus and long process of incus.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the bony roof of the specified ear structure?

options.label: A
options.text: Middle ear cavity – Tegmen antri

options.label: B
options.text: Mastoid antrum – Tegmen tympani

options.label: C
options.text: Middle ear cavity – Tegmen tympani

options.label: D
options.text: Mastoid antrum – Lamina papyracea

questions.correct_answer: C. Middle ear cavity – Tegmen tympani
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Middle ear cavity – Tegmen tympani

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear cavity, while the tegmen antri forms the roof of the mastoid antrum.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5

questions.text: Prussak's space is located between which of the following structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Eustachian tube and promontory

options.label: B
options.text: Pars flaccida and scutum laterally, and neck of malleus medially

options.label: C
options.text: Round window and oval window

options.label: D
options.text: Tensor tympani and tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Pars flaccida and scutum laterally, and neck of malleus medially
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pars flaccida and scutum laterally, and neck of malleus medially

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prussak’s space is bounded by the pars flaccida and scutum laterally and the neck of the malleus medially; it is the most common site for cholesteatoma formation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Körner’s septum is correct and clinically significant during mastoidectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a thick bony ridge separating the facial nerve and sigmoid sinus

options.label: B
options.text: It marks the end point of mastoid dissection and signifies completion of cell removal

options.label: C
options.text: It is a persistent petrosquamosal suture that may mislead the surgeon during mastoidectomy

options.label: D
options.text: It separates the middle ear cavity from the mastoid antrum and blocks disease spread

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a persistent petrosquamosal suture that may mislead the surgeon during mastoidectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is a persistent petrosquamosal suture that may mislead the surgeon during mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Körner’s septum is a persistent petrosquamosal suture that may mislead the surgeon during mastoidectomy into prematurely stopping drilling, potentially leaving residual disease in the petrous air cells.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 7
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 7

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary role of the transformer (impedance-matching) mechanism of the middle ear?

options.label: A
options.text: To amplify high-frequency sounds for vestibular perception

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the cochlea from loud sounds via stapedius and tensor tympani reflexes

options.label: C
options.text: To compensate for energy loss when sound passes from air in middle ear to fluid in inner ear

options.label: D
options.text: To equalize air pressure across the tympanic membrane via the Eustachian tube

questions.correct_answer: C. To compensate for energy loss when sound passes from air in middle ear to fluid in inner ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) To compensate for energy loss when sound passes from air in middle ear to fluid in inner ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transformer (impedance-matching) mechanism of the middle ear compensates for energy loss when sound passes from air to fluid by amplifying it before entry into the inner ear.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 15
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 15

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the middle ear muscle with its embryological arch origin, attachment, and nerve supply?

options.label: A
options.text: Stapedius – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by V3

options.label: B
options.text: Tensor tympani – 2nd arch – attaches to stapes – supplied by facial nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Tensor tympani – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by mandibular nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Stapedius – 3rd arch – attaches to footplate of stapes – supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Tensor tympani – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by mandibular nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tensor tympani – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by mandibular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tensor tympani is a 1st arch muscle that attaches to the malleus and is supplied by mandibular nerve (V3), while stapedius is a 2nd arch muscle that attaches to the stapes and is supplied by the facial nerve (VII).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86

questions.text: According to the Tos classification of pars flaccida retraction, which of the following best describes Type IV?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild retraction of the pars flaccida without touching ossicles

options.label: B
options.text: Retraction pocket touches the neck of the malleus only

options.label: C
options.text: Retraction pocket touches the head and neck of malleus, with partially visible sac contents

options.label: D
options.text: Retraction pocket involves head and neck of malleus with erosion of scutum

questions.correct_answer: D. Retraction pocket involves head and neck of malleus with erosion of scutum
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Retraction pocket involves head and neck of malleus with erosion of scutum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Tos classification, Type IV pars flaccida retraction involves the head and neck of the malleus with erosion of the scutum.

questions.text: A patient is Rinne negative with 256 Hz and 512 Hz tuning forks, but Rinne positive with 1024 Hz tuning fork. What is the most likely approximate degree of hearing loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 30–45 dB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rinne negative with 256 & 512 Hz but positive with 1024 Hz indicates a conductive hearing loss of approximately 30–45 dB.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: According to the WHO classification of hearing impairment, which of the following best corresponds to moderate hearing impairment?

options.label: A
options.text: 26–40 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in normal voice at 1 m

options.label: B
options.text: 41–60 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in raised voice at 1 m

options.label: C
options.text: 61–80 dB hearing loss, able to hear only when shouted into the better ear

options.label: D
options.text: ≥81 dB hearing loss, unable to hear even a shouted voice

questions.correct_answer: B. 41–60 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in raised voice at 1 m
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 41–60 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in raised voice at 1 m

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ WHO classifies moderate hearing impairment as 41–60 dB hearing loss, where the person can hear and repeat words spoken in a raised voice at 1 meter.
  • ➤ Ref: Report of the informal working group on prevention of deafness and hearing impairment programme planning, Geneva, 18-21 June 1991. Geneva: World Health Organization; 1991.
  • ➤ Ref: Report of the informal working group on prevention of deafness and hearing impairment programme planning, Geneva, 18-21 June 1991. Geneva: World Health Organization; 1991.

questions.text: The audiogram shown demonstrates which of the following types of hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal hearing

options.label: B
options.text: Mild sensorineural hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Mild conductive hearing loss

options.label: D
options.text: Mild mixed hearing loss

questions.correct_answer: C. Mild conductive hearing loss
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mild conductive hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An audiogram with normal bone conduction, elevated air conduction, and a consistent air-bone gap indicates mild conductive hearing loss.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 23
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 23

questions.text: The given audiogram shows a bilateral dip in hearing threshold around 4000 Hz with preserved hearing in lower frequencies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Presbycusis

options.label: B
options.text: Ototoxic hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Noise-induced hearing loss

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss

questions.correct_answer: C. Noise-induced hearing loss
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Noise-induced hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 4 kHz dip on audiogram with preserved low and high frequencies is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 23
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 23

questions.text: A factory worker is routinely exposed to noise levels of 94 dB during machinery operation. According to occupational safety guidelines, what is the maximum permissible daily exposure duration without hearing protection at this noise level?

options.label: A
options.text: 8 hours

options.label: B
options.text: 4 hours

options.label: C
options.text: 1 hour

options.label: D
options.text: 15 minutes

questions.correct_answer: C. 1 hour
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 hour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 94 dB, the maximum safe daily exposure without hearing protection is 1 hour, following the 3 dB exchange rule.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 38
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 38

questions.text: Which of the following clinical scenarios is most likely to show an absent stapedial reflex on tympanometry despite a normal cochlea?

options.label: A
options.text: Noise-induced hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Otitis externa

options.label: C
options.text: Facial nerve palsy proximal to the stapedius branch

options.label: D
options.text: Presbycusis

questions.correct_answer: C. Facial nerve palsy proximal to the stapedius branch
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Facial nerve palsy proximal to the stapedius branch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An absent stapedial reflex with a normal cochlea suggests a lesion in the facial nerve proximal to the nerve to stapedius.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 24
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 24

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the effect of hearing loss on the presence of the stapedial reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Present in both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Absent in conductive hearing loss due to impaired cochlear function

options.label: C
options.text: Absent in sensorineural hearing loss due to middle ear impedance mismatch

options.label: D
options.text: Absent in conductive hearing loss due to insufficient sound transmission to cochlea

questions.correct_answer: D. Absent in conductive hearing loss due to insufficient sound transmission to cochlea
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Absent in conductive hearing loss due to insufficient sound transmission to cochlea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The stapedial reflex is absent in conductive hearing loss due to poor sound conduction to the cochlea, despite a normal neural reflex arc.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 24
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 24

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intratympanic muscles is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Tensor tympani arises from the second pharyngeal arch and is supplied by facial nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Stapedius attaches to the malleus and tenses the tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Stapedius is supplied by a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3)

options.label: D
options.text: Tensor tympani is supplied by the mandibular nerve and dampens vibrations via the malleus

questions.correct_answer: D. Tensor tympani is supplied by the mandibular nerve and dampens vibrations via the malleus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tensor tympani is supplied by the mandibular nerve and dampens vibrations via the malleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tensor tympani is a first arch muscle supplied by mandibular nerve (V3) and attaches to the malleus to reduce sound vibrations.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 7
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 7

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the tympanic plexus and its functional role?

options.label: A
options.text: Formed by tympanic branch of vagus and supplies external auditory canal

options.label: B
options.text: Lies on the promontory and supplies lateral surface of tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Formed by tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal and sympathetic fibres, and contributes secretomotor fibres to parotid gland

options.label: D
options.text: Supplies motor innervation to the tensor tympani and stapedius muscles

questions.correct_answer: C. Formed by tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal and sympathetic fibres, and contributes secretomotor fibres to parotid gland
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Formed by tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal and sympathetic fibres, and contributes secretomotor fibres to parotid gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tympanic plexus, formed by the tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve and sympathetic fibres, supplies the middle ear and carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland via the lesser petrosal nerve.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the epithelial lining with its respective region in the middle ear or Eustachian tube?

options.label: A
options.text: Cartilaginous Eustachian tube – stratified squamous epithelium

options.label: B
options.text: Bony part of Eustachian tube – pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Mastoid air cells – flat nonciliated epithelium

options.label: D
options.text: Posterior tympanic cavity – ciliated columnar epithelium

questions.correct_answer: C. Mastoid air cells – flat nonciliated epithelium
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mastoid air cells – flat nonciliated epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mastoid air cells and epitympanum are lined by flat, nonciliated epithelium, while the Eustachian tube and tympanic cavity have ciliated or columnar epithelium depending on region.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8

questions.text: A patient with suspected unilateral hearing loss undergoes Rinne’s test, which is negative on the affected side. However, bone conduction is falsely perceived despite a suspected sensorineural lesion. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: Bone conduction bypasses the cochlea and stimulates the tympanic membrane directly

options.label: B
options.text: Air conduction is absent due to ossicular discontinuity

options.label: C
options.text: Sound is transmitted via bone to the opposite normal cochlea, leading to a false negative Rinne

options.label: D
options.text: The patient has mixed hearing loss with preserved air conduction on the opposite ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Sound is transmitted via bone to the opposite normal cochlea, leading to a false negative Rinne
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sound is transmitted via bone to the opposite normal cochlea, leading to a false negative Rinne

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In unilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne test may appear falsely negative due to transcranial transmission of bone-conducted sound to the better ear.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: In the Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) test, both the patient and a normal-hearing examiner have their external auditory meatus occluded. Which of the following correctly describes the expected findings in a patient with sensorineural hearing loss compared to conductive hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner perceive the sound for a shorter duration, whereas in sensorineural hearing loss, the durations are equal.

options.label: B
options.text: In conductive hearing loss, the patient hears the tuning fork for a shorter duration than the examiner, while in sensorineural hearing loss the durations are equal.

options.label: C
options.text: In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for the same duration; in sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears it for a shorter duration than the examiner.

options.label: D
options.text: In both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner.

questions.correct_answer: C. In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for the same duration; in sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears it for a shorter duration than the examiner.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for the same duration; in sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears it for a shorter duration than the examiner.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ABC test shows equal duration of bone conduction in conductive hearing loss but a reduced duration in sensorineural hearing loss due to impaired cochlear function.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: In the Bing test, a tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the ear canal is alternately closed and opened. Which of the following findings indicates conductive hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Sound is louder when the ear canal is occluded (Bing positive)

options.label: B
options.text: Sound is softer when the ear canal is occluded

options.label: C
options.text: No change in sound perception with occlusion (Bing negative)

options.label: D
options.text: Sound is louder only when both ears are occluded

questions.correct_answer: C. No change in sound perception with occlusion (Bing negative)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) No change in sound perception with occlusion (Bing negative)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bing test is negative (no change with occlusion) in conductive hearing loss and positive (sound gets louder with occlusion) in normal or sensorineural hearing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: Gelle’s test is performed using a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid while air pressure is increased in the ear canal using a Siegel’s speculum. In which of the following conditions will the patient perceive no change in the loudness of sound during the test?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal hearing

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Otitis externa

options.label: D
options.text: Otosclerosis with stapes fixation

questions.correct_answer: D. Otosclerosis with stapes fixation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Otosclerosis with stapes fixation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gelle’s test is negative (no change in bone-conducted sound) in ossicular fixation or discontinuity, such as in otosclerosis, and positive in normal and sensorineural hearing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the etiology of otosclerosis is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Otosclerosis is an autosomal recessive condition with complete penetrance

options.label: B
options.text: It is more common in females globally, but in India, males are more commonly affected

options.label: C
options.text: Otosclerosis commonly begins after 40 years of age

options.label: D
options.text: The most common site of origin is the round window membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. It is more common in females globally, but in India, males are more commonly affected
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is more common in females globally, but in India, males are more commonly affected

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis is an autosomal dominant disease affecting the enchondral bone at the fissula ante fenestram, more common in females globally, but in males in India, with onset typically between 20–30 years.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly matches the type of otosclerosis with its characteristic feature?

options.label: A
options.text: Stapedial otosclerosis is asymptomatic and causes no hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Cochlear otosclerosis is the most common and causes conductive hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Histologic otosclerosis shows bony changes but no clinical hearing impairment

options.label: D
options.text: Obliterative type of cochlear otosclerosis causes complete fixation of the stapes footplate

questions.correct_answer: C. Histologic otosclerosis shows bony changes but no clinical hearing impairment
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Histologic otosclerosis shows bony changes but no clinical hearing impairment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histologic otosclerosis is asymptomatic, while stapedial and cochlear types cause conductive and sensorineural hearing loss respectively, depending on the site of involvement.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and progressive hearing loss. On examination, a reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. She also complains of hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Imaging reveals a lesion involving the jugular foramen and hypotympanum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Vestibular schwannoma

options.label: B
options.text: Glomus tympanicum

options.label: C
options.text: Glomus jugulare

options.label: D
options.text: Cholesteatoma

questions.correct_answer: C. Glomus jugulare
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glomus jugulare

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus jugulare tumors arise from the dome of the jugular bulb, invade the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and may cause lower cranial nerve (IX–XII) involvement and vascular compression.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and hoarseness. Otoscopy reveals a reddish mass behind a perforated tympanic membrane. Imaging shows invasion of the mastoid, jugular foramen, and extension toward the nasopharynx. Which of the following statements about the spread of the suspected tumor is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It commonly metastasizes to liver and kidneys in over 10% of cases

options.label: B
options.text: It can spread intracranially to posterior and middle cranial fossae

options.label: C
options.text: It never involves the eustachian tube or nasopharynx

options.label: D
options.text: It originates from the cochlea and spreads to the tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. It can spread intracranially to posterior and middle cranial fossae
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It can spread intracranially to posterior and middle cranial fossae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus tumors may spread locally to the middle ear, mastoid, skull base, nasopharynx, and intracranial fossae, and rarely metastasize to lungs or bones (4%).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with right-sided pulsatile tinnitus, slowly progressive hearing loss, and occasional dizziness. Otoscopy reveals a bluish, bulging tympanic membrane with a red mass visible behind it. The mass blanches and pulsates with pressure applied via Siegel’s speculum. She also complains of mild hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Which of the following is not true regarding the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: It typically presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Brown’s sign is usually negative

options.label: C
options.text: Cranial nerves IX to XII may be involved in late stages

options.label: D
options.text: The tumor may produce catecholamines, causing systemic symptoms

questions.correct_answer: B. Brown’s sign is usually negative
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brown’s sign is usually negative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus tumors commonly cause pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss, show positive Brown’s sign, may involve lower cranial nerves in late stages, and can occasionally secrete catecholamines.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rotation test (Barany's chair test) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The test is contraindicated in patients with congenital absence of the external auditory canal

options.label: B
options.text: It allows individual assessment of each labyrinth by stimulating one side at a time

options.label: C
options.text: It can be used when caloric testing is not feasible due to canal malformation

options.label: D
options.text: Normal post-rotation nystagmus lasts less than 10 seconds

questions.correct_answer: C. It can be used when caloric testing is not feasible due to canal malformation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It can be used when caloric testing is not feasible due to canal malformation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rotation test is a valuable vestibular assessment when caloric testing is not feasible, especially in congenital malformations where the external ear canal has not developed.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Modified Kobrak test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It assesses cochlear function by irrigating the external auditory canal with warm water

options.label: B
options.text: A normal response is absence of nystagmus even after 40 mL of cold water irrigation

options.label: C
options.text: If nystagmus is elicited only after 20 mL of ice water, the labyrinth is considered hyperactive

options.label: D
options.text: No nystagmus even after 40 mL of ice water irrigation suggests a dead labyrinth

questions.correct_answer: D. No nystagmus even after 40 mL of ice water irrigation suggests a dead labyrinth
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) No nystagmus even after 40 mL of ice water irrigation suggests a dead labyrinth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the Modified Kobrak test, absence of nystagmus even after 40 mL of ice water irrigation indicates a dead labyrinth.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 43
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 43

questions.text: According to Alexander’s law, which of the following correctly describes 3rd-degree nystagmus?

options.label: A
options.text: Nystagmus present only when looking in the direction of fast phase

options.label: B
options.text: Stronger than 2nd-degree nystagmus and seen even when looking in the direction of slow phase

options.label: C
options.text: Seen only when the patient looks straight ahead

options.label: D
options.text: Present in central lesions and suppressed with optic fixation

questions.correct_answer: B. Stronger than 2nd-degree nystagmus and seen even when looking in the direction of slow phase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stronger than 2nd-degree nystagmus and seen even when looking in the direction of slow phase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Third-degree nystagmus is the most intense form and is present even when the patient looks in the direction of the slow component, as per Alexander’s law.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the galvanic test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps differentiate cochlear from vestibular dysfunction

options.label: B
options.text: It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ

options.label: C
options.text: The test is performed with the patient seated and eyes open

options.label: D
options.text: Normally, the patient sways away from the side of anodal stimulation

questions.correct_answer: B. It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The galvanic test is a vestibular assessment that helps differentiate end organ (labyrinthine) lesions from vestibular nerve lesions by evaluating postural sway in response to anodal stimulation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most suggestive of nonorganic hearing loss (NOHL)?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Shadow curve is present during bone conduction testing in unilateral hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Stenger test is positive when the patient denies hearing louder sound in the feigned deaf ear

options.label: D
options.text: Electric response audiometry confirms no auditory activity in patients with NOHL

questions.correct_answer: C. Stenger test is positive when the patient denies hearing louder sound in the feigned deaf ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stenger test is positive when the patient denies hearing louder sound in the feigned deaf ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive Stenger test, where a patient denies hearing a louder sound in the feigned deaf ear, is diagnostic of nonorganic hearing loss.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 36
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 36

questions.text: According to the Noise Pollution (Regulation and Control) Rules 2000 by the Ministry of Environment and Forest, Govt. of India, which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The permissible daytime noise limit in a residential area is 65 dB(A) Leq

options.label: B
options.text: The permissible night-time noise limit in a silent zone is 45 dB(A) Leq

options.label: C
options.text: The permissible daytime noise limit in an industrial area is 75 dB(A) Leq

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The permissible daytime noise limit in an industrial area is 75 dB(A) Leq

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per Noise Pollution Rules 2000, the permissible daytime noise limit in industrial areas is 75 dB(A) Leq.

  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 34

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ototoxicity is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Furosemide causes irreversible damage to the outer hair cells in all cases

options.label: B
options.text: Neomycin and kanamycin are primarily vestibulotoxic drugs

options.label: C
options.text: Deferoxamine can cause high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in children

options.label: D
options.text: Salicylate-induced hearing loss is due to hair cell destruction seen on electron microscopy

questions.correct_answer: C. Deferoxamine can cause high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in children
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Deferoxamine can cause high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Deferoxamine is an ototoxic agent that can cause high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, especially in children receiving long-term therapy.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 33
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 33

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding distraction techniques used in pediatric hearing assessment is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Distraction test is reliable only after 12 months of age when the child develops speech

options.label: B
options.text: It uses pure tone audiometry to assess hearing thresholds in infants

options.label: C
options.text: It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound

options.label: D
options.text: Only high-frequency sounds are used, such as 8 kHz rattles or whistles

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Distraction testing is performed at 6–7 months of age to assess hearing by observing the child’s head-turning response to various sound stimuli presented out of sight.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding central auditory tests is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Binaural tests are typically abnormal in cortical lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Dichotic tests present distorted speech to both ears simultaneously

options.label: C
options.text: Monotic tests assess difficulty in understanding distorted speech and are affected in cortical lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Central auditory tests are routinely used as part of standard audiological assessment

questions.correct_answer: C. Monotic tests assess difficulty in understanding distorted speech and are affected in cortical lesions
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Monotic tests assess difficulty in understanding distorted speech and are affected in cortical lesions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Monotic tests help identify central auditory dysfunction by evaluating how well distorted speech is understood, and are particularly affected in cortical brain lesions.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 28
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 28

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Threshold Tone Decay Test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: A tone of 1000 Hz is presented at 20 dB above threshold for 60 seconds to assess cochlear pathology

options.label: B
options.text: A decay of more than 25 dB suggests a cochlear lesion

options.label: C
options.text: A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: The test is primarily used to assess the presence of middle ear pathology

questions.correct_answer: C. A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Threshold Tone Decay Test detects retrocochlear lesions by measuring how much above threshold a 4000 Hz tone must be presented for the patient to hear it continuously for 60 seconds.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: Which of the following statements about recruitment is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Recruitment is typically seen in retrocochlear lesions such as vestibular schwannoma

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to improved hearing of soft sounds in the affected ear

options.label: C
options.text: Recruitment is detected using the Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test and is common in cochlear lesions like Ménière’s disease

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with recruitment are ideal candidates for hearing aids

questions.correct_answer: C. Recruitment is detected using the Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test and is common in cochlear lesions like Ménière’s disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Recruitment is detected using the Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test and is common in cochlear lesions like Ménière’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recruitment is an abnormal increase in loudness perception seen in cochlear lesions like Ménière’s disease and is detected using the Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance (ABLB) test.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the division of the vestibular system?

options.label: A
options.text: The central vestibular system includes the utricle, saccule, and semicircular ducts

options.label: B
options.text: The peripheral vestibular system is responsible for integrating impulses with other sensory systems

options.label: C
options.text: The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS

options.label: D
options.text: The peripheral vestibular system includes the cochlea and auditory nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The central vestibular system consists of vestibular nuclei and fibre tracts in the CNS, which integrate vestibular impulses to maintain body balance.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 17
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 17

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the bony labyrinth is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The cochlea makes one complete turn around the modiolus and forms the promontory

options.label: B
options.text: The non-ampullated ends of the superior and lateral semicircular canals form the crus commune

options.label: C
options.text: The vestibule contains openings for all three semicircular canals and lodges both saccule and utricle

options.label: D
options.text: The osseous spiral lamina completely divides the bony cochlea into two separate chambers

questions.correct_answer: C. The vestibule contains openings for all three semicircular canals and lodges both saccule and utricle
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The vestibule contains openings for all three semicircular canals and lodges both saccule and utricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vestibule is the central chamber of the bony labyrinth that receives five semicircular canal openings and lodges both the saccule and utricle.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 9
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 9

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) testing is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Wave I of ABR is generated from the cochlear nucleus

options.label: B
options.text: ABR is an invasive test used to measure cortical auditory responses

options.label: C
options.text: ABR is useful in detecting retrocochlear lesions such as acoustic neuroma

options.label: D
options.text: ABR primarily evaluates hearing sensitivity below 500 Hz

questions.correct_answer: C. ABR is useful in detecting retrocochlear lesions such as acoustic neuroma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ABR is useful in detecting retrocochlear lesions such as acoustic neuroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ABR is a non-invasive test that evaluates auditory pathway integrity and is especially useful in diagnosing retrocochlear pathologies such as acoustic neuroma.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly explains the importance of phase differential between the oval and round windows in the auditory system?

options.label: A
options.text: Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration

options.label: B
options.text: Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window

options.label: D
options.text: Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

questions.correct_answer: D. Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phase differential between the oval and round windows ensures alternate compression and rarefaction, preventing cancellation of waves and enabling perilymph movement for effective hearing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the physiological basis for body equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture

options.label: B
options.text: The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs

options.label: C
options.text: Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance

questions.correct_answer: C. Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Equilibrium is maintained by a bilateral vestibular push-pull system integrated with visual and somatosensory input, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal responses.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma

options.label: B
options.text: The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments

options.label: C
options.text: A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%

questions.correct_answer: C. A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A SISI score of 70–100% is indicative of cochlear pathology , helping differentiate it from retrocochlear and conductive causes of hearing loss.
  • ➤ cochlear pathology
  • ➤ retrocochlear
  • ➤ conductive
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Auditory Steady State Response (ASSR) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: ASSR uses transient stimuli like clicks and tone bursts to generate a response

options.label: B
options.text: ASSR is unable to detect hearing loss greater than 80 dB in infants

options.label: C
options.text: ASSR provides frequency-specific audiograms using modulated pure tones

options.label: D
options.text: ASSR is not suitable for early selection of candidates for cochlear implantation

questions.correct_answer: C. ASSR provides frequency-specific audiograms using modulated pure tones
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ASSR provides frequency-specific audiograms using modulated pure tones

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ASSR uses modulated pure tone signals to generate frequency-specific audiograms and is effective in detecting hearing losses above 80 dB, aiding early cochlear implant candidacy decisions.

  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: Which of the following responses is correctly matched with its behavioral observation audiometry reflex in infants?

options.label: A

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most characteristically associated with otosyphilis?

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) is correct?

options.text: Noise at frequencies between 2000–3000 Hz is particularly damaging to the cochlea

options.label: C

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED) is correct?

options.label: A

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Romberg test is correct?

questions.text: Which of the following findings during a Hallpike manoeuvre is most suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) due to a peripheral cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate onset of nystagmus, direction changing, non-fatiguable

options.label: B
options.text: Nystagmus with no vertigo and variable direction in each head position

options.label: C
options.text: Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable

options.label: D
options.text: Nystagmus lasting over 1 minute, present in straight head-hanging position only

questions.correct_answer: C. Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BPPV is indicated by nystagmus with a latency of 2–20 seconds, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguability on repeated Hallpike manoeuvre testing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Electronystagmography (ENG) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: ENG is based on detecting auditory evoked potentials from the cochlea

options.label: B
options.text: ENG cannot detect nystagmus that is not visible to the naked eye

options.label: C
options.text: ENG uses corneoretinal potentials recorded via electrodes placed around the eyes

options.label: D
options.text: ENG is only useful for recording spontaneous nystagmus and not stimulus-induced types

questions.correct_answer: C. ENG uses corneoretinal potentials recorded via electrodes placed around the eyes
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ENG uses corneoretinal potentials recorded via electrodes placed around the eyes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Electronystagmography records eye movements by detecting corneoretinal potentials using electrodes and can identify both spontaneous and stimulus-induced nystagmus, including those not visible to the naked eye.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most consistent with midline cerebellar dysfunction?

options.label: A
options.text: Adiadochokinesia and abnormal finger–nose test

options.label: B
options.text: Dysmetria and rebound phenomenon

options.label: C
options.text: Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait

options.label: D
options.text: Hemiplegia with spasticity and positive Babinski sign

questions.correct_answer: C. Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Midline cerebellar dysfunction typically presents with truncal ataxia, wide-based gait, falls in any direction, and difficulty turning while walking.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42

questions.text: Which of the following statements about acoustic trauma is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Acoustic trauma always presents with a temporary threshold shift that later becomes permanent

options.label: B
options.text: Impulse noise from gunfire can reach up to 100 dB SPL, which is usually safe for the cochlea

options.label: C
options.text: Exposure to impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the organ of Corti

options.label: D
options.text: Acoustic trauma primarily affects the middle ear and spares the cochlea

questions.correct_answer: C. Exposure to impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the organ of Corti
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exposure to impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the organ of Corti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acoustic trauma from impulse noise above 140 dB can cause mechanical damage to the cochlea, particularly the organ of Corti, leading to permanent sensorineural hearing loss.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 34
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 34

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: SNHL is typically associated with an air-bone gap on audiometry

options.label: B
options.text: Speech discrimination scores are usually preserved in SNHL

options.label: C
options.text: SNHL often affects high frequencies and may show poor speech discrimination

options.label: D
options.text: Rinne test is negative in SNHL due to reduced bone conduction

questions.correct_answer: C. SNHL often affects high frequencies and may show poor speech discrimination
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) SNHL often affects high frequencies and may show poor speech discrimination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sensorineural hearing loss often affects high frequencies and is associated with poor speech discrimination and no air-bone gap on audiometry.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 32
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 32

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: OAEs are absent in auditory neuropathy due to damage to cochlear hair cells

options.label: B
options.text: Distortion Product OAEs (DPOAEs) are evoked using single click stimuli at 80–85 dB SPL

options.label: C
options.text: OAEs are useful in distinguishing cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss

options.label: D
options.text: OAEs disappear in VIIIth nerve pathology due to nerve dysfunction

questions.correct_answer: C. OAEs are useful in distinguishing cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) OAEs are useful in distinguishing cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OAEs help differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear hearing loss by being absent in cochlear pathology but preserved in retrocochlear disorders like auditory neuropathy.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 28
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 28

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the cause of motion sickness?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct overstimulation of the cochlear nerve due to loud sounds

options.label: B
options.text: Isolated dysfunction of the cerebellum without vestibular input

options.label: C
options.text: Mismatch of inputs from visual, vestibular, and somatosensory systems reaching vestibular nuclei and cerebellum

options.label: D
options.text: Excess endolymph production in the semicircular canals during motion

questions.correct_answer: C. Mismatch of inputs from visual, vestibular, and somatosensory systems reaching vestibular nuclei and cerebellum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mismatch of inputs from visual, vestibular, and somatosensory systems reaching vestibular nuclei and cerebellum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Motion sickness occurs due to sensory mismatch between visual, vestibular, and somatosensory inputs reaching the vestibular nuclei and cerebellum.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cochlear function and auditory transduction is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: All frequencies stimulate the entire length of the basilar membrane uniformly

options.label: B
options.text: Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics

options.label: C
options.text: Low-frequency sounds stimulate the basal turn of the cochlea, while high frequencies reach the apex

options.label: D
options.text: The primary auditory neurons are multipolar and located in the cochlear nuclei

questions.correct_answer: B. Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shearing between the basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, generating cochlear microphonics and initiating auditory transduction based on frequency-specific displacement along the basilar membrane.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Play Audiometry is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Play audiometry conditions a child to perform a task like placing a block in a bucket upon hearing a sound signal

options.label: B
options.text: Play audiometry is only useful in infants below 1 year of age

options.label: C
options.text: Play audiometry cannot determine ear-specific hearing thresholds

options.label: D
options.text: Play audiometry does not require any reinforcement or reward during the procedure

questions.correct_answer: A. Play audiometry conditions a child to perform a task like placing a block in a bucket upon hearing a sound signal
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Play audiometry conditions a child to perform a task like placing a block in a bucket upon hearing a sound signal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Play audiometry is used in children aged 2–5 years by conditioning them to perform a simple task in response to sound, allowing ear-specific threshold determination with positive reinforcement.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118

questions.text: Which of the following statements about labyrinthitis and its etiologies is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral labyrinthitis commonly spreads from the middle ear through the oval window

options.label: B
options.text: Bacterial labyrinthitis cannot occur through CSF pathways

options.label: C
options.text: Herpes simplex and influenza are definitively proven to directly invade the inner ear

options.label: D
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss following meningitis is a well-known clinical consequence of bacterial labyrinthitis

questions.correct_answer: D. Sensorineural hearing loss following meningitis is a well-known clinical consequence of bacterial labyrinthitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss following meningitis is a well-known clinical consequence of bacterial labyrinthitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sensorineural hearing loss is a recognized complication of bacterial labyrinthitis, especially following meningitis due to destruction of the membranous labyrinth.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 33
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 33

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Presbycusis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: In neural presbycusis, speech discrimination is preserved despite high-frequency hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Strial (metabolic) presbycusis typically presents with a sloping audiogram and poor speech discrimination

options.label: C
options.text: Cochlear conductive presbycusis is due to stiffening of the basilar membrane and produces a sloping audiogram

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory presbycusis begins at the apex of the cochlea and affects low-frequency hearing first

questions.correct_answer: C. Cochlear conductive presbycusis is due to stiffening of the basilar membrane and produces a sloping audiogram
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cochlear conductive presbycusis is due to stiffening of the basilar membrane and produces a sloping audiogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cochlear conductive presbycusis results from stiffening of the basilar membrane and is characterized by a sloping audiogram pattern.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 36
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 36

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the optokinetic test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The fast component of optokinetic nystagmus follows the direction of the moving stripes

options.label: B
options.text: The test is primarily used to diagnose peripheral vestibular dysfunction

options.label: C
options.text: Optokinetic nystagmus abnormalities suggest a lesion in the brainstem or cerebral hemisphere

options.label: D
options.text: The test involves tracking horizontal lines in a stationary field

questions.correct_answer: C. Optokinetic nystagmus abnormalities suggest a lesion in the brainstem or cerebral hemisphere
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Optokinetic nystagmus abnormalities suggest a lesion in the brainstem or cerebral hemisphere

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The optokinetic test helps identify central lesions, as abnormalities in optokinetic nystagmus indicate dysfunction in the brainstem or cerebral hemispheres.

  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44

questions.text: Based on the communication model for hearing-impaired individuals, which of the following pairs correctly matches a receptive faculty with its corresponding input modality?

options.label: A
options.text: Auditory faculty – Written language

options.label: B
options.text: Tactile faculty – Sound signal via cochlear implant

options.label: C
options.text: Visual faculty – Lip reading and sign language

options.label: D
options.text: Auditory faculty – Vibrotactile aid

questions.correct_answer: C. Visual faculty – Lip reading and sign language
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Visual faculty – Lip reading and sign language

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hearing-impaired individuals, the visual faculty facilitates receptive skills like lip reading, sign language, and reading written language.

  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 120

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a risk factor for hearing loss in children as per the Joint Committee on Infant Hearing (1994) guidelines?

options.label: A
options.text: Craniofacial anomalies involving the ear or pinna

options.label: B
options.text: Mechanical ventilation for more than 5 days

options.label: C
options.text: Birth weight of more than 3000 g

options.label: D
options.text: Use of aminoglycosides in multiple courses

questions.correct_answer: C. Birth weight of more than 3000 g
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Birth weight of more than 3000 g

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children with birth weight <1500 g, craniofacial anomalies, ototoxic drug exposure, or prolonged ventilation are at increased risk of hearing loss and should be screened early.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Speech Audiometry in children is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves conditioning the child to respond to pure tones with a play activity

options.label: B
options.text: It is primarily used in neonates using non-verbal behavioral cues

options.label: C
options.text: It is not useful in assessing speech discrimination abilities

options.label: D
options.text: It involves asking the child to name or point to objects as the examiner's voice is gradually lowered

questions.correct_answer: D. It involves asking the child to name or point to objects as the examiner's voice is gradually lowered
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It involves asking the child to name or point to objects as the examiner's voice is gradually lowered

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Speech audiometry in children evaluates hearing level and speech discrimination by asking them to name or identify objects as voice intensity is gradually reduced.
