Ans. C) Petrositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Petrositis classically presents as Gradenigo syndrome with VIth nerve palsy, retro-orbital pain, and persistent otorrhea, due to infection spreading to the petrous apex along pneumatized tracts.
  • ➤ Petrositis
  • ➤ Gradenigo syndrome
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 79
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 79

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with chronic ear discharge presents with sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. Examination reveals spontaneous nystagmus with the quick component toward the affected side. Audiometry shows mild sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following best describes the underlying condition and its appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Suppurative labyrinthitis; immediate surgical drainage and systemic corticosteroids

options.label: B
options.text: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo; canalith repositioning and vestibular suppressants

options.label: C
options.text: Meniere's disease; sodium restriction and betahistine therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Diffuse serous labyrinthitis; systemic antibiotics and possible mastoidectomy if conservative measures fail

questions.correct_answer: D. Diffuse serous labyrinthitis; systemic antibiotics and possible mastoidectomy if conservative measures fail
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diffuse serous labyrinthitis; systemic antibiotics and possible mastoidectomy if conservative measures fail

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse serous labyrinthitis is a reversible intralabyrinthine inflammation presenting with vertigo, nausea, and SNHL, and is managed with antibiotics, vestibular sedatives, and mastoidectomy if required.
  • ➤ Diffuse serous labyrinthitis
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 80
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 80

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of chronic ear discharge presents with headache, fever, neck stiffness, and focal neurological deficits including hemiplegia and aphasia. On examination, he has papilledema and a dilated pupil. MRI shows pus collection between the dura and arachnoid. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate lumbar puncture for CSF analysis

options.label: B
options.text: High-dose oral antibiotics and observation

options.label: C
options.text: Craniotomy and intravenous antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Cortical mastoidectomy followed by conservative treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. Craniotomy and intravenous antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Craniotomy and intravenous antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subdural abscess from otitis media presents with meningeal signs, focal deficits, and raised intracranial pressure, and requires urgent neurosurgical drainage and intravenous antibiotics ; lumbar puncture is contraindicated.
  • ➤ Subdural abscess
  • ➤ urgent neurosurgical drainage and intravenous antibiotics
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 81
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 81

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media and recent onset of profuse ear discharge presents with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors. On examination, he has tenderness over the posterior mastoid region (Griesinger’s sign) and papilledema. Contrast-enhanced CT shows a “delta sign” in the posterior cranial fossa. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start oral antibiotics and schedule outpatient follow-up

options.label: B
options.text: Perform cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy with sinus exposure and IV antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Proceed directly with ligation of internal jugular vein

options.label: D
options.text: Start anticoagulants and observe for resolution

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy with sinus exposure and IV antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perform cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy with sinus exposure and IV antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis is a serious intracranial complication of otitis media and requires urgent surgical drainage via mastoidectomy along with intravenous antibiotics; Griesinger's sign and "delta sign" on imaging support the diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 85
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 85

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a dull tympanic membrane and fluid behind it, suggestive of otitis media with effusion (OME). What should be the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe antihistamines and decongestants

options.label: B
options.text: Evaluate the nasopharynx to rule out carcinoma

options.label: C
options.text: Insert a grommet after myringotomy

options.label: D
options.text: Perform tympanoplasty

questions.correct_answer: B. Evaluate the nasopharynx to rule out carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Evaluate the nasopharynx to rule out carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unilateral otitis media with effusion in an elderly patient should prompt evaluation for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in the Fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 251
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 251

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with a history of chronic otitis media presents with deep retro-orbital pain, diplopia, and persistent ear discharge. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bezold's abscess

options.label: B
options.text: Gradenigo’s syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Mastoiditis

options.label: D
options.text: Cholesteatoma

questions.correct_answer: B. Gradenigo’s syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Graden go’s syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gradenigo’s syndrome, seen in petrositis, presents with retro-orbital pain (CN V), diplopia (CN VI), and persistent otorrhea and is managed surgically.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 94
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 94

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a standard indication for performing a postaural (Wilde’s) incision in ENT surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Cortical mastoidectomy

options.label: B
options.text: Tympanoplasty for anterior perforation

options.label: C
options.text: Grommet insertion in otitis media with effusion

options.label: D
options.text: Exposure of vertical segment of facial nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Grommet insertion in otitis media with effusion
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Grommet insertion in otitis media with effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postaural (Wilde’s) incision is used in mastoid surgeries, tympanoplasty with anterior perforations, and to expose the vertical facial nerve segment—not for simple transcanal procedures like grommet insertion.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 401
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 401

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes Schuller’s view in radiological imaging of the temporal bone?

options.label: A
options.text: It uses a 15° cephalocaudal beam and does not show the attic or antrum clearly

options.label: B
options.text: It is primarily used to assess nasopharyngeal tumors extending into the Eustachian tube

options.label: C
options.text: It shows the key area of the mastoid including antrum and upper attic, using a 30° cephalocaudal beam

options.label: D
options.text: The sagittal plane is perpendicular to the film and the internal and external auditory canals are separated

questions.correct_answer: C. It shows the key area of the mastoid including antrum and upper attic, using a 30° cephalocaudal beam
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It shows the key area of the mastoid including antrum and upper attic, using a 30° cephalocaudal beam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schuller’s view uses a 30° cephalocaudal beam with the sagittal plane parallel to the film and is useful for visualizing the mastoid antrum, attic, and sinodural angle, making it ideal for assessing mastoiditis, cholesteatoma, and petrous fractures.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is a myringotome. Which of the following statements regarding this instrument and its use is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to remove granulation tissue from the middle ear in CSOM

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to incise the tympanic membrane during myringotomy

options.label: C
options.text: It is a curette used to excise the adenoids

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to raise the tympanomeatal flap in tympanoplasty

questions.correct_answer: B. It is used to incise the tympanic membrane during myringotomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is used to incise the tympanic membrane during myringotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A myringotome is a surgical instrument used to make a controlled incision in the tympanic membrane during myringotomy, often for middle ear drainage or grommet insertion.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 451
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 451

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor. Which of the following statements regarding this instrument is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used for nasal septum elevation during septoplasty

options.label: B
options.text: It is manually held throughout mastoid surgery to retract soft tissues

options.label: C
options.text: It is self-retaining and commonly used to retract soft tissue flaps during mastoidectomy

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to excise granulation tissue from the middle ear cavity

questions.correct_answer: C. It is self-retaining and commonly used to retract soft tissue flaps during mastoidectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is self-retaining and commonly used to retract soft tissue flaps during mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after flap elevation and provides a stable, hands-free operative field.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 451
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 451

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is a mastoid gouge. Which of the following statements about its use is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to elevate the tympanomeatal flap in tympanoplasty

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to suction fluid from the middle ear during myringotomy

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to remove bone during mastoid surgery and comes in various sizes

options.label: D
options.text: It is primarily used to cauterize granulation tissue in the ear canal

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used to remove bone during mastoid surgery and comes in various sizes
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is used to remove bone during mastoid surgery and comes in various sizes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mastoid gouge is a manual surgical instrument available in various sizes and used to remove bone during mastoid surgery.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and choose the correct statement regarding its surgical use:

options.label: A
options.text: Freer’s elevator – used to elevate nasal septal flaps

options.label: B
options.text: Farabeuf periosteal elevator – used to elevate periosteum from mastoid cortex in mastoidectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Lempert’s endaural speculum – used to spread the external auditory canal during endaural approach

options.label: D
options.text: Mollison’s mastoid retractor – used to retract postaural soft tissues during mastoid surgery

questions.correct_answer: B. Farabeuf periosteal elevator – used to elevate periosteum from mastoid cortex in mastoidectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Farabeuf periosteal elevator – used to elevate periosteum from mastoid cortex in mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Farabeuf periosteal elevator is used in mastoidectomy to elevate the periosteum from the mastoid cortex after postaural flap elevation.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of fever, severe earache, vomiting, and reduced hearing. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, red tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks, and a yellow spot is visible. What stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) is this child most likely in?

options.label: A
options.text: Stage of tubal occlusion

options.label: B
options.text: Stage of presuppuration

options.label: C
options.text: Stage of suppuration

options.label: D
options.text: Stage of resolution

questions.correct_answer: C. Stage of suppuration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stage of suppuration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The suppurative stage of ASOM is marked by bulging tympanic membrane, yellow spot, severe earache, and high fever , indicating accumulation of pus in the middle ear.
  • ➤ suppurative stage of ASOM
  • ➤ bulging tympanic membrane, yellow spot, severe earache, and high fever
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62

questions.text: A 25-year-old man experiences sudden severe ear pain, hearing loss, and a sense of fullness in the right ear during rapid descent on a flight. Otoscopy reveals a congested, retracted tympanic membrane, and audiometry shows conductive hearing loss. What is the most likely underlying mechanism of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute bacterial infection of the middle ear

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammation of cochlear membranes due to viral labyrinthitis

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of Eustachian tube to equalize middle ear pressure during descent

options.label: D
options.text: Serous otitis media due to allergic rhinitis

questions.correct_answer: C. Failure of Eustachian tube to equalize middle ear pressure during descent
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Failure of Eustachian tube to equalize middle ear pressure during descent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aero-otitis media occurs when the Eustachian tube fails to equalize middle ear pressure during descent, leading to TM retraction, pain, and conductive hearing loss.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 66
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 66

questions.text: Which of the following theories of cholesteatoma origin involves retraction pocket formation due to invagination of tympanic membrane epithelium?

options.label: A
options.text: Ruedi’s theory

options.label: B
options.text: Wittmaack’s theory

options.label: C
options.text: Sade’s theory

options.label: D
options.text: Habermann’s theory

questions.correct_answer: B. Wittmaack’s theory
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wittmaack’s theory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wittmaack’s theory explains cholesteatoma formation due to retraction pocket of tympanic membrane epithelium invaginating into the middle ear.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67

questions.text: Which of the following features helps differentiate congenital cholesteatoma from acquired cholesteatoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Associated with tympanic membrane perforation

options.label: B
options.text: Presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Occurs due to epithelial migration through a marginal perforation

options.label: D
options.text: Typically arises from retraction pocket of pars flaccida or pars tensa

questions.correct_answer: B. Presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital cholesteatoma presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, while acquired cholesteatoma is associated with retraction pockets or TM perforation.
  • ➤ Congenital cholesteatoma presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, while acquired cholesteatoma is associated with retraction pockets or TM perforation.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with complaints of persistent ear discharge that is foul-smelling and scanty. Otoscopic examination reveals a marginal perforation in the posterosuperior quadrant, and granulation tissue is seen. Audiometry reveals mixed hearing loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Tubotympanic type of CSOM

options.label: B
options.text: Serous otitis media

options.label: C
options.text: Atticoantral type of CSOM

options.label: D
options.text: Otitis externa

questions.correct_answer: C. Atticoantral type of CSOM
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atticoantral type of CSOM

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atticoantral (unsafe) CSOM is characterized by scanty, foul-smelling discharge, marginal or attic perforation, granulations, and a higher risk of complications and mixed hearing loss.
  • ➤ Atticoantral (unsafe) CSOM
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 69
  • ➤ Ref:-P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 69

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with chronic ear discharge and recent onset vertigo complains of dizziness while cleaning his ear or during Valsalva. On examination, applying pressure on the tragus elicits vertigo and horizontal nystagmus towards the same side. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and associated mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Diffuse serous labyrinthitis due to acute otitis media, ampullofugal endolymph flow

options.label: B
options.text: Circumscribed labyrinthitis with ampullopetal displacement of the cupula

options.label: C
options.text: Meniere’s disease with increased endolymphatic pressure in saccule and utricle

options.label: D
options.text: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo with canalithiasis in posterior semicircular canal

questions.correct_answer: B. Circumscribed labyrinthitis with ampullopetal displacement of the cupula
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Circumscribed labyrinthitis with ampullopetal displacement of the cupula.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Circumscribed labyrinthitis , commonly due to cholesteatoma , presents with pressure-induced vertigo and nystagmus towards the affected side due to ampullopetal endolymph flow .
  • ➤ Circumscribed labyrinthitis
  • ➤ cholesteatoma
  • ➤ pressure-induced vertigo and nystagmus towards the affected side
  • ➤ ampullopetal endolymph flow

  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 80

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a long-standing history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents with severe headache, vomiting, drowsiness, and right-sided hemiparesis. CT scan reveals a ring-enhancing lesion in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the appropriate approach?

options.label: A
options.text: Temporal lobe glioma; initiate radiotherapy immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Otogenic brain abscess; initiate intravenous antibiotics and consider neurosurgical drainage

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebellar stroke; manage with anticoagulants and supportive care

options.label: D
options.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage; confirm with lumbar puncture and manage in ICU

questions.correct_answer: B. Otogenic brain abscess; initiate intravenous antibiotics and consider neurosurgical drainage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otogenic brain abscess; initiate intravenous antibiotics and consider neurosurgical drainage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otogenic brain abscess commonly complicates chronic suppurative otitis media and presents with raised intracranial pressure and focal neurological signs; management includes antibiotics, neurosurgical drainage, and subsequent mastoid surgery.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 83
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 83

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with intermittent hearing difficulty. Otoscopy reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane with visible air-fluid levels. Audiometry suggests a fluctuating hearing loss. What is the most likely type of hearing loss and its associated condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss – Otosclerosis

options.label: B
options.text: Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Otitis media with effusion

options.label: C
options.text: Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss – Presbycusis

options.label: D
options.text: Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Meniere’s disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Otitis media with effusion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fluctuating conductive hearing loss – Otitis media with effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluctuating conductive hearing loss is characteristic of otitis media with effusion, whereas fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss is seen in Meniere’s disease.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 115, 243
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 115, 243

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test used to detect perilymph fistula?

options.label: A
options.text: It reliably detects fistulas involving the posterior semicircular canal

options.label: B
options.text: The test is done with the patient sitting upright with head in neutral position

options.label: C
options.text: Cold water irrigation normally causes nystagmus to the same side

options.label: D
options.text: Normal nystagmus response follows the COWS pattern – Cold Opposite, Warm Same

questions.correct_answer: D. Normal nystagmus response follows the COWS pattern – Cold Opposite, Warm Same
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Normal nystagmus response follows the COWS pattern – Cold Opposite, Warm Same

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test stimulates the lateral semicircular canal and in normal individuals, produces nystagmus following the COWS rule—Cold Opposite, Warm Same.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 43
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 43

questions.text: Which of the following structures is best visualized in a Stenver’s view of the temporal bone?

options.label: A
options.text: Eustachian tube

options.label: B
options.text: Arcuate eminence and petrous pyramid

options.label: C
options.text: Nasopharynx and skull base

options.label: D
options.text: Frontal sinus and ethmoid air cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Arcuate eminence and petrous pyramid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arcuate eminence and petrous pyramid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stenver’s view aligns the petrous ridge parallel to the film and is used to visualize the petrous pyramid, arcuate eminence, internal auditory meatus, cochlea, vestibule, and mastoid antrum.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Submentovertical (SMV) view used in radiological imaging of the skull base?

options.label: A
options.text: X-ray beam is directed cephalocaudally with occiput on the film

options.label: B
options.text: It visualizes external auditory canal, middle ear cleft, sphenoid sinus, and carotid canal

options.label: C
options.text: It is primarily used to assess frontal and ethmoid sinuses

options.label: D
options.text: It fails to demonstrate foramina at the base of skull like foramen ovale and spinosum

questions.correct_answer: B. It visualizes external auditory canal, middle ear cleft, sphenoid sinus, and carotid canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It visualizes external auditory canal, middle ear cleft, sphenoid sinus, and carotid canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The submentovertical (SMV) view visualizes the EAC, middle ear cleft, internal auditory canal, sphenoid sinus, carotid canal, and skull base foramina like foramen ovale and spinosum.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433

questions.text: The instrument shown is Lempert’s endaural retractor. Which of the following statements regarding this instrument is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to remove granulation tissue from the middle ear

options.label: B
options.text: It is used for retraction of soft tissues in the postaural approach

options.label: C
options.text: It is used in the endaural approach and has a central blade that retracts the temporalis muscle

options.label: D
options.text: It is used for elevating the tympanomeatal flap during tympanoplasty

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used in the endaural approach and has a central blade that retracts the temporalis muscle
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is used in the endaural approach and has a central blade that retracts the temporalis muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lempert’s endaural retractor is used in the endaural approach to ear surgery, with lateral blades retracting skin flaps and a central blade to retract the temporalis muscle.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and select the correct statement regarding its use:

options.label: A
options.text: Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Freer’s elevator – used to elevate tympanomeatal flap

options.label: C
options.text: Myringotome – used for incision in tympanic membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Mollison’s retractor – used for soft tissue retraction in postaural mastoidectomy

questions.correct_answer: A. Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lempert’s curette – used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lempert’s curette is used in mastoidectomy to remove bony septa and granulation tissue from the mastoid air cells.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct indication for myringotomy in the treatment of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM)?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild earache with no tympanic membrane bulging

options.label: B
options.text: Acute pain with bulging tympanic membrane despite antibiotic therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Resolution of symptoms after 3 days of antibiotic therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss persisting for 1 week after symptom relief

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute pain with bulging tympanic membrane despite antibiotic therapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute pain with bulging tympanic membrane despite antibiotic therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringotomy is indicated in ASOM when there is persistent pain with bulging tympanic membrane, incomplete resolution despite antibiotics, or effusion lasting more than 12 weeks.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with no prior history of ear discharge or otitis media is found to have a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane, with visible keratin debris. Otoscopy confirms attic perforation. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for this presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Perforation due to acute otitis media

options.label: B
options.text: Epithelial migration through a marginal perforation

options.label: C
options.text: Invagination of pars flaccida due to persistent negative pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Direct extension from congenital epithelial rests

questions.correct_answer: C. Invagination of pars flaccida due to persistent negative pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Invagination of pars flaccida due to persistent negative pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary acquired cholesteatoma most commonly arises due to invagination of pars flaccida from persistent negative pressure, forming a retraction pocket that accumulates keratin and expands toward the middle ear.
  • ➤ Primary acquired cholesteatoma
  • ➤ invagination of pars flaccida
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with painless ear discharge, multiple tympanic membrane perforations, and sudden-onset facial paralysis. Examination reveals pale granulations in the middle ear, and the hearing loss is severe and out of proportion to clinical findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute Suppurative Otitis Media

options.label: B
options.text: Cholesteatomatous Otitis Media

options.label: C
options.text: Tubercular Otitis Media

options.label: D
options.text: Otomycosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Tubercular Otitis Media
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tubercular Otitis Media

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubercular Otitis Media presents with painless discharge, multiple tympanic membrane perforations, severe hearing loss, and early facial paralysis, especially in children.
  • ➤ Tubercular Otitis Media
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 74
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 74

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with acute otitis media develops sudden onset facial asymmetry. On otoscopy, bulging of the tympanic membrane is noted. Which of the following is most likely true regarding this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent nerve damage is likely and urgent decompression is mandatory

options.label: B
options.text: Facial nerve paralysis is due to cholesteatoma-induced destruction of the facial canal

options.label: C
options.text: Facial nerve recovery is expected with systemic antibiotics, and surgery may be needed in resistant cases

options.label: D
options.text: Facial paralysis is due to vestibular schwannoma arising in the internal auditory canal

questions.correct_answer: C. Facial nerve recovery is expected with systemic antibiotics, and surgery may be needed in resistant cases
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Facial nerve recovery is expected with systemic antibiotics, and surgery may be needed in resistant cases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Facial paralysis in acute otitis media is typically reversible with systemic antibiotics , though surgery like myringotomy or mastoidectomy may be indicated in resistant cases.
  • ➤ acute otitis media
  • ➤ systemic antibiotics
  • ➤ myringotomy or mastoidectomy
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 80
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 80

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with chronic ear infection develops sudden severe vertigo, vomiting, and complete hearing loss in one ear. Examination reveals spontaneous nystagmus with the quick component directed to the opposite ear. He appears toxic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Diffuse serous labyrinthitis

options.label: B
options.text: Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis

options.label: C
options.text: Meniere’s disease

options.label: D
options.text: Vestibular neuronitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis presents with severe vertigo, vomiting, complete hearing loss, and spontaneous nystagmus toward the healthy side, and requires urgent antibiotic therapy and possible surgical intervention.
  • ➤ Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 81
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 81

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, neck rigidity, photophobia, vomiting, and altered sensorium. He had a history of ear discharge for the past few days. CSF analysis reveals turbid fluid, high protein, low glucose, and predominant polymorphs. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is most commonly associated with otitis externa in children

options.label: B
options.text: Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in all cases of suspected meningitis

options.label: C
options.text: CT scan is the definitive diagnostic test for bacterial meningitis

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media in children

questions.correct_answer: D. It is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media in children
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meningitis is the most frequent intracranial complication of otitis media, diagnosed via CSF analysis and treated with antibiotics and, when needed, mastoid surgery.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 82
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 82

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with a recent history of chronic otitis media presents with severe headache, diplopia, and episodes of blurred vision. Fundoscopy shows papilloedema. CSF examination reveals an opening pressure of 310 mm H₂O but normal cell counts, proteins, sugars, and sterile cultures. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Pyogenic meningitis

options.label: B
options.text: Otitic hydrocephalus

options.label: C
options.text: Subdural abscess

options.label: D
options.text: Tuberculous meningitis

questions.correct_answer: B. Otitic hydrocephalus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otitic hydrocephalus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otitic hydrocephalus presents with raised intracranial pressure and normal CSF findings, typically due to lateral sinus thrombosis following middle ear infection.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 85
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 85

questions.text: Which of the following Wullstein types of tympanoplasty is indicated when the malleus and incus are absent, and the graft is placed directly over the stapes head?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I

options.label: B
options.text: Type II

options.label: C
options.text: Type III

options.label: D
options.text: Type IV

questions.correct_answer: C. Type III
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Type III tympanoplasty (Wullstein classification), when malleus and incus are absent, the graft is placed directly over the stapes head.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 30
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 30

questions.text: Which of the following features is most suggestive of primary carcinoma of the middle ear rather than simple chronic suppurative otitis media?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductive hearing loss with central perforation

options.label: B
options.text: Intermittent ear discharge responding to antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Persistent foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge with severe nocturnal pain in a 55-year-old

options.label: D
options.text: History of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections

questions.correct_answer: C. Persistent foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge with severe nocturnal pain in a 55-year-old
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Persistent foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge with severe nocturnal pain in a 55-year-old

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carcinoma of the middle ear should be suspected in adults aged 40–60 with persistent blood-stained discharge, severe nocturnal pain, facial palsy, or granulations not responding to routine treatment.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 111
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 111

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) develops neurological symptoms. Which of the following is the most common intracranial complication associated with CSOM?

options.label: A
options.text: Meningitis

options.label: B
options.text: Brain Abscess

options.label: C
options.text: Epidural Abscess

options.label: D
options.text: Subdural Empyema

questions.correct_answer: A. Meningitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meningitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . A brain abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, but it is less common than meningitis. It typically presents with localized neurological symptoms depending on the area of the brain affected , along with signs of increased intracranial pressure .
  • • Option B
  • • serious complication
  • • less common than meningitis.
  • • typically presents
  • • localized neurological symptoms
  • • area
  • • brain affected
  • • signs of increased intracranial pressure
  • • Option C . An epidural abscess is a collection of pus between the dura mater and the skull . While it can occur as a complication of CSOM , it is less common compared to meningitis.
  • • Option C
  • • collection
  • • pus
  • • dura mater
  • • skull
  • • occur
  • • complication of CSOM
  • • Option D . Subdural empyema, a collection of pus between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane , is a rare but serious complication of CSOM . However, meningitis remains the more common intracranial complication .
  • • Option D
  • • collection of pus
  • • dura mater
  • • arachnoid membrane
  • • rare
  • • serious complication
  • • CSOM
  • • meningitis
  • • remains
  • • common intracranial complication

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ M eningitis is the most common intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) , characterized by the spread of infection to the meninges leading to inflammation and associated neurological symptoms .
  • ➤ eningitis
  • ➤ most common intracranial complication
  • ➤ chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)
  • ➤ spread of infection
  • ➤ meninges
  • ➤ inflammation
  • ➤ associated neurological symptoms
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 75-85
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 75-85

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Law’s view (lateral oblique view) used in radiological assessment of the mastoid?

options.label: A
options.text: It clearly demonstrates attic, aditus, and antrum

options.label: B
options.text: The sagittal plane of the skull is perpendicular to the film

options.label: C
options.text: It shows external auditory canal superimposed on the internal auditory canal

options.label: D
options.text: The X-ray beam is projected at a 45° caudocranial angle

questions.correct_answer: C. It shows external auditory canal superimposed on the internal auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It shows external auditory canal superimposed on the internal auditory canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Law’s view (lateral oblique), the sagittal plane is parallel to the film and the X-ray beam is angled 15° cephalocaudal, showing the EAC superimposed on the IAC but not well visualizing the attic, aditus, or antrum.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Towne’s view in radiology of the temporal bone is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a lateral view used to visualize mastoid air cell septations

options.label: B
options.text: It provides comparison of both petrous pyramids and is useful in acoustic neuroma evaluation

options.label: C
options.text: It is a posteroanterior projection with no angle used to visualize frontal sinuses

options.label: D
options.text: It does not show internal auditory canal or cochlea clearly

questions.correct_answer: B. It provides comparison of both petrous pyramids and is useful in acoustic neuroma evaluation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It provides comparison of both petrous pyramids and is useful in acoustic neuroma evaluation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Towne’s view is an AP view with 30° cranial tilt used to compare both petrous pyramids and visualize structures like the IAC and cochlea, especially useful in acoustic neuroma and petrositis assessment.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Transorbital view in radiographic imaging is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a lateral oblique view that best shows mastoid air cells and sinodural angle

options.label: B
options.text: It projects the petrous pyramid through the occiput and does not visualize the internal auditory canal

options.label: C
options.text: It is used for comparison of both petrous pyramids and is helpful in diagnosing acoustic neuroma

options.label: D
options.text: It cannot visualize the cochlea or labyrinth due to orbital interference

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used for comparison of both petrous pyramids and is helpful in diagnosing acoustic neuroma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is used for comparison of both petrous pyramids and is helpful in diagnosing acoustic neuroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The transorbital view projects the petrous pyramid, IAC, cochlea, and labyrinth through the orbit and is useful for comparing both sides, especially in cases of acoustic neuroma.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 433

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown and choose the correct statement regarding its use in ENT surgery:

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to remove granulation tissue from the middle ear during tympanoplasty

options.label: B
options.text: It is used for retracting nasal mucosa during septoplasty

options.label: C
options.text: It is a self-retaining retractor used to hold soft tissues apart during mastoidectomy

options.label: D
options.text: It is primarily used for nasal bone fracture reduction

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a self-retaining retractor used to hold soft tissues apart during mastoidectomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is a self-retaining retractor used to hold soft tissues apart during mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mollison’s mastoid retractor is a self-retaining and haemostatic instrument used during mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues and maintain a clear surgical field.

  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 451

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is Lempert’s endaural speculum. Which of the following statements is true regarding this instrument and its use?

options.text: It is used to retract the tympanomeatal flap during tympanoplasty

options.label: C
