questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and select the correct statement regarding its use:

options.label: A
options.text: Freer’s elevator – used for raising tympanomeatal flap in tympanoplasty

options.label: B
options.text: MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker – used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove septa

options.label: C
options.text: Lempert’s curette – used to remove nasal polyps in outpatient setting

options.label: D
options.text: Mollison’s retractor – used to retract skin flaps in neck dissection

questions.correct_answer: B. MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker – used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove septa
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker – used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove septa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker is a dual-ended instrument used in mastoid surgery to explore air cells and remove bony septa or granulations.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 452

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with chronic ear discharge and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a posterosuperior marginal perforation with granulation tissue. A diagnosis of secondary acquired cholesteatoma is made. Which of the following best describes the most likely mechanism of cholesteatoma formation in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Invagination of pars flaccida due to eustachian tube dysfunction

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperplasia of basal layer of skin in the external auditory canal

options.label: C
options.text: Migration of squamous epithelium through a marginal perforation

options.label: D
options.text: Persistence of embryonic epithelial cell rests in the middle ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Migration of squamous epithelium through a marginal perforation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Migration of squamous epithelium through a marginal perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secondary acquired cholesteatoma arises most commonly from epithelial migration through a pre-existing marginal perforation, especially in the posterosuperior quadrant.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 67

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a 3-week history of ear discharge following acute otitis media. Examination reveals mastoid tenderness, sagging of the posterosuperior canal wall, and a dull, bulging tympanic membrane. The child also has a fever and appears toxic. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start topical antibiotic ear drops and discharge the patient

options.label: B
options.text: Prescribe oral antihistamines and nasal decongestants

options.label: C
options.text: Hospitalize, start systemic antibiotics, and consider myringotomy

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule a hearing test and review after 2 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Hospitalize, start systemic antibiotics, and consider myringotomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hospitalize, start systemic antibiotics, and consider myringotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute mastoiditis presents with postauricular pain, discharge, mastoid tenderness, and systemic features; it requires hospitalization, IV antibiotics, and myringotomy ± mastoidectomy.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 77
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 77

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media presents with persistent headache, foul-smelling pulsatile ear discharge, and malaise. During mastoid surgery, pus is found between the bone and dura without overt meningeal signs. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Extradural abscess

options.label: B
options.text: Subdural empyema

options.label: C
options.text: Brain abscess

options.label: D
options.text: Meningitis

questions.correct_answer: A. Extradural abscess
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Extradural abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extradural abscess is a localized collection of pus between bone and dura in otitis media, often discovered intraoperatively and managed by mastoidectomy and antibiotics.
  • ➤ Extradural abscess
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 81
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 81

questions.text: A child presents with hearing loss and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane with visible air-fluid levels and bubbles. Tympanometry shows a flat curve. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: High-dose systemic antibiotics for 10 days

options.label: B
options.text: Myringotomy with grommet insertion

options.label: C
options.text: Cortical mastoidectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Radical mastoidectomy

questions.correct_answer: B. Myringotomy with grommet insertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Myringotomy with grommet insertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In otitis media with effusion (OME), myringotomy with grommet insertion is the treatment of choice to ventilate the middle ear and drain sterile effusion.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 65
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 65

questions.text: A patient with chronic otitis media and cholesteatoma develops vertigo when pressure is applied to the tragus. However, there is no visible evidence of a perilymph fistula. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: Diffuse suppurative labyrinthitis

options.label: B
options.text: True positive fistula sign

options.label: C
options.text: False positive fistula sign (Hennebert’s sign)

options.label: D
options.text: False negative fistula sign

questions.correct_answer: C. False positive fistula sign (Hennebert’s sign)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) False positive fistula sign (Hennebert’s sign)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A false positive fistula sign (Hennebert’s sign) is seen when vertigo occurs without an actual perilymph fistula, commonly in congenital syphilis and late-stage Ménière’s disease.
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 56
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 56

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the branches of the facial nerve is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Chorda tympani arises from the tympanic segment and supplies the parotid gland

options.label: B
options.text: Nerve to stapedius arises at the level of the second genu and supplies the stapedius muscle

options.label: C
options.text: Greater superficial petrosal nerve arises from the mastoid segment and supplies the submandibular gland

options.label: D
options.text: Cervical branch of the facial nerve carries taste sensation from posterior one-third of the tongue

questions.correct_answer: B. Nerve to stapedius arises at the level of the second genu and supplies the stapedius muscle
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nerve to stapedius arises at the level of the second genu and supplies the stapedius muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nerve to stapedius arises at the second genu of the facial nerve and supplies the stapedius muscle in the middle ear.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 94–95.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 94–95.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about surgical landmarks for locating the facial nerve during parotid surgery is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The facial nerve lies lateral to the cartilaginous pointer of the external auditory canal

options.label: B
options.text: The facial nerve lies between the posterior belly of digastric and the styloid process

options.label: C
options.text: The facial nerve lies deep and posterior to the tympanomastoid suture

options.label: D
options.text: The facial nerve passes medially to the styloid process during its extracranial course

questions.correct_answer: B. The facial nerve lies between the posterior belly of digastric and the styloid process
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The facial nerve lies between the posterior belly of digastric and the styloid process

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During parotid surgery, the facial nerve lies between the posterior belly of the digastric muscle and the styloid process, serving as a reliable surgical landmark.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.

questions.text: Which of the following topodiagnostic tests is used to identify a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion in a case of lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrogustometry showing reduced taste sensation on the anterior tongue

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of stapedial reflex detected by tympanometry

options.label: C
options.text: Schirmer test showing decreased lacrimation on the affected side

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced salivation from the parotid gland

questions.correct_answer: C. Schirmer test showing decreased lacrimation on the affected side
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schirmer test showing decreased lacrimation on the affected side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decreased lacrimation on Schirmer test suggests a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion, where secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland originate.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 102.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 102.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the role of components in a conventional hearing aid?

options.label: A
options.text: The microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier magnifies them, and the receiver converts them back to sound

options.label: B
options.text: The amplifier picks up sound and sends it directly to the tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: The receiver captures sound and converts it into electrical signals for processing

options.label: D
options.text: The microphone sends electrical signals directly to the cochlea through a bone conduction pathway

questions.correct_answer: A. The microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier magnifies them, and the receiver converts them back to sound
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier magnifies them, and the receiver converts them back to sound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a conventional hearing aid, the microphone converts sound into electrical signals, the amplifier boosts them, and the receiver converts them back to sound delivered to the ear.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct indication for Bone-Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) placement?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic ear discharge not amenable to medical or surgical treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with intact external ear canal

options.label: C
options.text: Intermittent tinnitus with normal hearing thresholds

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss in a patient who prefers cosmetic hearing aid solutions

questions.correct_answer: A. Chronic ear discharge not amenable to medical or surgical treatment
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic ear discharge not amenable to medical or surgical treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BAHA is indicated in patients with chronic ear discharge, canal atresia, or single-sided deafness when conventional air-conduction hearing aids are not feasible.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most strongly associated with better clinical outcomes following cochlear implantation?

options.label: A
options.text: Longer duration of deafness with no prior use of hearing aids

options.label: B
options.text: Younger age at implantation, especially in prelingually deaf children

options.label: C
options.text: Prelingual adults with no auditory experience before implantation

options.label: D
options.text: Use of single-channel implants with auditory training

questions.correct_answer: B. Younger age at implantation, especially in prelingually deaf children
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Younger age at implantation, especially in prelingually deaf children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Younger age at implantation, particularly in prelingually deaf children, is a strong predictor of successful outcomes with cochlear implants due to higher neural plasticity.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the types of tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: Subjective tinnitus is heard by both the patient and the examiner

options.label: B
options.text: Objective tinnitus is always associated with sensorineural hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Objective tinnitus can be heard by the examiner, often using a stethoscope

options.label: D
options.text: Subjective tinnitus indicates a middle ear pathology that generates audible sounds

questions.correct_answer: C. Objective tinnitus can be heard by the examiner, often using a stethoscope
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Objective tinnitus can be heard by the examiner, often using a stethoscope

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinnitus is classified as subjective (heard only by the patient) or objective (can also be heard by the examiner using a stethoscope).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Bell palsy is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Bell palsy most commonly affects young males and is often associated with trigeminal neuralgia

options.label: B
options.text: The most common cause of Bell palsy is trauma to the facial nerve during mastoid surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Bell palsy is an idiopathic, acute-onset, peripheral facial paralysis with viral and ischemic etiologies being most common

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical decompression of the facial nerve is the first-line treatment in all patients with Bell palsy

questions.correct_answer: C. Bell palsy is an idiopathic, acute-onset, peripheral facial paralysis with viral and ischemic etiologies being most common
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bell palsy is an idiopathic, acute-onset, peripheral facial paralysis with viral and ischemic etiologies being most common

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bell palsy is an idiopathic, acute-onset, lower motor neuron facial paralysis commonly caused by viral infections and vascular ischemia.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 97–100.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 97–100.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of peripheral facial paralysis due to faulty regeneration of parasympathetic fibers?

options.label: A
options.text: Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation)

options.label: B
options.text: Exposure keratitis due to loss of tear film

options.label: C
options.text: Synkinesis caused by cross motor innervation

options.label: D
options.text: Frey’s syndrome resulting from parotid surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation) occur due to faulty regeneration of parasympathetic fibers following facial nerve injury, causing lacrimation during eating.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: ABI stimulates the cochlear nerve directly through an electrode placed in the cochlea

options.label: B
options.text: ABI is indicated in patients with unilateral vestibular schwannoma and normal hearing on the opposite side

options.label: C
options.text: ABI is placed over the cochlear nucleus complex in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle

options.label: D
options.text: ABI provides better speech recognition outcomes than multichannel cochlear implants

questions.correct_answer: C. ABI is placed over the cochlear nucleus complex in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ABI is placed over the cochlear nucleus complex in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auditory Brainstem Implants (ABIs) are placed in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle to stimulate the cochlear nucleus complex when the cochlear nerve is absent or non-functional.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 127
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 127

questions.text: Which of the following is an essential candidacy criterion for cochlear implantation?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with good benefit from hearing aids

options.label: B
options.text: Bilateral conductive hearing loss with intact cognitive function

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss with little or no benefit from hearing aids

options.label: D
options.text: Severe hearing loss in one ear with normal hearing in the other

questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss with little or no benefit from hearing aids
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss with little or no benefit from hearing aids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cochlear implants are indicated in patients with bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss who derive minimal or no benefit from hearing aids.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Bone-Anchored Hearing Aids (BAHA) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: BAHA transmits sound through the external auditory canal and ossicular chain

options.label: B
options.text: BAHA is contraindicated in conductive or mixed hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: The sound processor of BAHA is implanted at the time of initial surgery

options.label: D
options.text: BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone, bypassing the external and middle ear

questions.correct_answer: D. BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone, bypassing the external and middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone, bypassing the external and middle ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BAHA transmits sound vibrations directly to the cochlea via bone conduction, bypassing the external auditory canal and middle ear.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the indications for hearing aid use is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss is a contraindication for hearing aids due to inevitable sound distortion

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive hearing loss is not treated with hearing aids under any circumstance

options.label: D
options.text: Hearing aids are delayed in deaf children until after 5 years of age to assess speech development

questions.correct_answer: A. Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hearing aids are indicated for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical treatment.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding hyperkinetic disorders of the facial nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: Blepharospasm usually affects only one eye and is most commonly caused by acoustic neuroma

options.label: B
options.text: Botulinum toxin is ineffective in hemifacial spasm but useful in treating exposure keratitis

options.label: C
options.text: Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle

options.label: D
options.text: Selective nerve section is contraindicated in the treatment of essential hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm

questions.correct_answer: C. Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemifacial spasm may be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle and is treatable by microvascular decompression or botulinum toxin.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103–104.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103–104.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding transverse fractures of the temporal bone?

options.label: A
options.text: Most commonly caused by parietal blows and associated with conductive hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Often associated with bleeding from the ear and injury to ossicles

options.label: C
options.text: Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases

options.label: D
options.text: Characterized by CSF otorrhea that is usually mixed with blood

questions.correct_answer: C. Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse temporal bone fractures typically cause sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis due to injury to the labyrinth or proximal facial nerve.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100–101.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100–101.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about causes of tinnitus is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Objective tinnitus is most commonly psychogenic and occurs without any identifiable physical source

options.label: B
options.text: Venous hum and vascular lesions like glomus tumors are typical causes of subjective tinnitus

options.label: C
options.text: Clicking tinnitus due to palatal myoclonus is an example of subjective tinnitus that occurs during swallowing

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

questions.correct_answer: D. Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Objective tinnitus may result from physical sources like palatal myoclonus or a patulous eustachian tube, producing sounds synchronized with muscle activity or respiration.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is characteristic of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Recurrent facial paralysis, ear discharge, and conductive hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Recurrent facial paralysis, lip swelling, and fissured tongue

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral facial paralysis, ocular pain, and nasal crusting

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden facial paralysis, mastoid tenderness, and vertigo

questions.correct_answer: B. Recurrent facial paralysis, lip swelling, and fissured tongue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Recurrent facial paralysis, lip swelling, and fissured tongue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome is defined by a triad of recurrent facial paralysis, swelling of the lips, and a fissured tongue.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding surgical management of facial nerve injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoglossal-facial anastomosis restores facial movement without any impact on tongue function

options.label: B
options.text: End-to-end anastomosis is preferred when the nerve gap is large and requires tension to bridge

options.label: C
options.text: Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis

options.label: D
options.text: Decompression involves rerouting the entire facial nerve to relieve mechanical pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cable grafting is indicated when the gap between severed facial nerve ends is too large to allow tension-free end-to-end anastomosis.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 105.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 105.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes implantable middle ear hearing aids?

options.label: A
options.text: They amplify sound in the external canal and transmit it acoustically to the tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Piezoelectric devices work by generating a magnetic field around the ossicles

options.label: C
options.text: Electromagnetic devices use crystal expansion to directly stimulate the cochlea

options.label: D
options.text: They work by delivering mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain, bypassing the external auditory canal

questions.correct_answer: D. They work by delivering mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain, bypassing the external auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) They work by delivering mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain, bypassing the external auditory canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Implantable middle ear hearing aids deliver mechanical vibrations directly to the ossicular chain, bypassing the external auditory canal.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cochlear implants is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Cochlear implants deliver amplified sound signals directly to the hair cells in the cochlea

options.label: B
options.text: The external component includes the receiver and electrode array, both surgically implanted behind the ear

options.label: C
options.text: Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve via electrical impulses transmitted through an electrode array placed in the scala tympani

options.label: D
options.text: The speech processor in a cochlear implant is always body-worn and cannot be placed behind the ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve via electrical impulses transmitted through an electrode array placed in the scala tympani
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve via electrical impulses transmitted through an electrode array placed in the scala tympani

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cochlear implants stimulate the auditory nerve through electrical impulses delivered by an electrode array placed in the scala tympani.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 125

questions.text: Which of the following is an essential part of preoperative evaluation for cochlear implantation?

options.label: A
options.text: Routine use of tympanoplasty to improve candidacy

options.label: B
options.text: Cochlear implantation can proceed without imaging if audiometry is conclusive

options.label: C
options.text: Vaccination against hepatitis B is mandatory before implantation

options.label: D
options.text: Audiological, medical, imaging, speech-language, and psychological evaluations are required to assess suitability and predict outcomes

questions.correct_answer: D. Audiological, medical, imaging, speech-language, and psychological evaluations are required to assess suitability and predict outcomes
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Audiological, medical, imaging, speech-language, and psychological evaluations are required to assess suitability and predict outcomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cochlear implant candidacy requires thorough evaluation including audiological, medical, imaging, speech-language, and psychological assessments.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 126
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 126

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding types of hearing aids is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Spectacle hearing aids are the most commonly used type due to their multifunctionality

options.label: B
options.text: Bone conduction hearing aids are ideal for patients with intact ear canals and no external ear pathology

options.label: C
options.text: In-the-ear (ITE) hearing aids are mainly used in children with congenital deafness

options.label: D
options.text: Body-worn hearing aids allow high amplification with minimal feedback and are useful in children with congenital deafness

questions.correct_answer: D. Body-worn hearing aids allow high amplification with minimal feedback and are useful in children with congenital deafness
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Body-worn hearing aids allow high amplification with minimal feedback and are useful in children with congenital deafness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Body-worn hearing aids offer strong amplification with minimal feedback and are especially beneficial for children with congenital deafness.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Vibrant Soundbridge device is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The internal component contains a microphone and amplifier that transmit sound to the tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: The external component is surgically implanted into the mastoid bone

options.label: C
options.text: The Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) is connected to the tympanic membrane and stimulates it directly

options.label: D
options.text: The internal component includes a receiver and a Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) connected to the incus

questions.correct_answer: D. The internal component includes a receiver and a Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) connected to the incus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The internal component includes a receiver and a Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) connected to the incus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Vibrant Soundbridge's internal component includes a receiver and a Floating Mass Transducer (FMT) that is connected to the incus to deliver mechanical sound stimulation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 123

questions.text: During middle ear surgery, which of the following correctly describes a key surgical landmark for identifying the facial nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: The facial nerve lies lateral to the short process of incus at the level of aditus

options.label: B
options.text: The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus

options.label: C
options.text: The tympanic segment of the facial nerve starts at the posterior end of the digastric ridge

options.label: D
options.text: The geniculate ganglion is located posterior to the processus cochleariformis

questions.correct_answer: B. The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus in its vertical (mastoid) segment, serving as a key landmark in middle ear surgery.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus

options.label: B
options.text: It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen

options.label: C
options.text: It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is the shortest and narrowest portion, making it highly susceptible to compression-induced facial paralysis.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 90
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 90

questions.text: Which of the following statements about CROS (Contralateral Routing of Signals) hearing aids is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear

options.label: B
options.text: CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity

options.label: D
options.text: CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

questions.correct_answer: D. CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CROS hearing aids route sound from the deaf ear to the better ear, helping with sound localization in cases of single-sided deafness.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding cochlear implant surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: The electrode array is placed in the scala vestibuli to directly stimulate the organ of Corti

options.label: B
options.text: The receiver/stimulator is placed externally and anchored over the skin above the mastoid bone

options.label: C
options.text: The facial recess approach involves cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy to access the round window niche

options.label: D
options.text: The suprameatal recess approach requires a wide mastoid cavity and stapedectomy for electrode insertion

questions.correct_answer: C. The facial recess approach involves cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy to access the round window niche
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The facial recess approach involves cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy to access the round window niche

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cochlear implant surgery commonly uses the facial recess approach, involving cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy to access the round window for electrode insertion.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 126
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 126

questions.text: Which of the following is a referred cause of earache transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve)?

options.label: A
options.text: Cervical spondylosis involving C2 and C3 nerve roots

options.label: B
options.text: Impacted third molar causing temporomandibular joint pain

options.label: C
options.text: Malignant ulcer of the tonsil or soft palate

options.label: D
options.text: Ulcerative lesion of the larynx involving the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. Malignant ulcer of the tonsil or soft palate
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malignant ulcer of the tonsil or soft palate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant or ulcerative lesions of the tonsil or soft palate refer pain to the ear via the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX cranial nerve).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg.128
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg.128

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: Tinnitus is a disease of the auditory nerve and always requires surgical treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Hearing aids are only used to amplify sound and have no role in managing tinnitus

options.label: C
options.text: Tinnitus maskers may provide temporary relief due to the phenomenon of residual inhibition

options.label: D
options.text: Sedatives are avoided in all tinnitus cases due to risk of worsening symptoms

questions.correct_answer: C. Tinnitus maskers may provide temporary relief due to the phenomenon of residual inhibition
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tinnitus maskers may provide temporary relief due to the phenomenon of residual inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinnitus maskers can provide symptom relief through residual inhibition, especially in patients without hearing loss.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: TRT aims to completely mask tinnitus sounds using high-volume white noise

options.label: B
options.text: TRT is based on the principle that tinnitus itself causes distress, not emotional reactions

options.label: C
options.text: TRT involves habituation of both emotional reaction and conscious perception of tinnitus

options.label: D
options.text: TRT is a short-term therapy lasting 2–3 weeks and does not require counseling

questions.correct_answer: C. TRT involves habituation of both emotional reaction and conscious perception of tinnitus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) TRT involves habituation of both emotional reaction and conscious perception of tinnitus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinnitus Retraining Therapy (TRT) involves habituation of both emotional response and conscious perception of tinnitus using counseling and sound therapy over a long duration.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 131
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 131

questions.text: A patient develops unilateral tearing while eating, several months after recovery from facial nerve injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Frey’s syndrome due to misdirection of fibers to the auriculotemporal nerve

options.label: B
options.text: Crocodile tears syndrome due to misdirected parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland

options.label: C
options.text: Palatal myoclonus with associated lacrimal hyperactivity

options.label: D
options.text: Glossopharyngeal neuralgia with referred lacrimation

questions.correct_answer: B. Crocodile tears syndrome due to misdirected parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crocodile tears syndrome due to misdirected parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crocodile tears syndrome is caused by misdirected parasympathetic fibers after facial nerve trauma, leading to unilateral lacrimation while eating.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 23, 110, 113, 251
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg.
  • ➤ 23, 110, 113, 251
